review_body: My son and I stayed here for one night during the Rugby World Cup. The previous night we were at the Hilton Odaiba. We had dinner with friends at the Ninja Restaurant next door to the Akasaka Excel so decided to stay here. It is your typical Japanese hotel. We arrived an hour before check-in but couldn't go to our room (normal in Japan). We came back and had to queue for some time as there was only one staff member on the desk. This was not your usual Japanese service.The room was small but fine. The beds were very comfortable and there were some nice shower amenities. The window was only single glaze but there was very little traffic outside at night so noise wasn't a problem. We got some breakfast at the 7-11 in the basement of the hotel.This hotel was fine for a night.

This comfortable hotel is conveniently located in downtownTokyo, which makes it easily accessible for tourists who want to be in the center of everything. This hotel looks rather like every other hotel (there's not a lot of "unique traits"), but it's still nicely designed and the staff are pleasant and helpful. The rooms have sufficient space for the standard tourist's needs, and the shower in particular was fantastic (not a universal thing for hotels). We had a Nespresso machine in our room.

Whilst there wasn’t much soul to this hotel & the reception staff seemed a little robotic... the location is good (sits on top of the GINZA line). We could run in the park behind the hotel and to The Imperial Palace. One downside (As with many hotels in winter) was the room heater (fixed thermostat) But... fortunately we could open the window for some cooler “Air-conditioning”.

I’ve travelled to Tokyo many times and lived here. In February 2020 we stayed with kids in 20s and grandma. Couldn’t have picked a better location- the hotel is on top of a station with a bunch of subway lines so few train changes required & a only a couple of stops to everything. No long underground treks to get to the platform so easy for grandma. In-room Nespresso machines & a box of weetbix from home meant we could pace ourselves in the morning. Good sized rooms, great service, great showers. Great restaurants across the road & in hotel.

Location:This is the hotel from where nothing is very far. Train station is less than 5 minutes walk. Roopongi, Shinzuku, Ginza, Shibya all can be reached in 20 Minutes or so. You get a direct bus to hotel to/from Airport and that's the easiest way to reach hotel.Room:I used 19 sq m room and that was enough for a single person. The room like most hotels in Tokyo was small but sufficient. Breakfast:The Breakfast buffet has lots of options even for vegetarians.Service:The staff is very helpful and you don't face nay challenge even if you don't speak Japanese language.

Small but functional rooms but no choice of pillows which were uncomfortable. Decent but expensive Japanese restaurant but poor range of food and limited fresh fruit at breakfast buffet. Helpful and friendly employees

Great location, just across the road from the underground station. Plenty of restaurants and shops nearby. Good nightlife around the hotel just in a walking distance. The rooms aren’t massive but a decent size for Tokyo. The shower room was massive with everything you need. Highly recommended!

I chose this hotel for its central location, and I couldn't have been happier with it. It was close to five Metro lines (Akasaka-mitsuke & Nagatacho stations) which made getting around the city via train very easy. The hotel also had a 7-11 in its lobby, which was very convenient for getting water and snacks (more on this later).The check-in process was very smooth when I arrived at around 7pm. My room was on the larger side for Japanese rooms, with a good sized desk, clean, and located on the quiet side of the building facing some green space surrounding a few government buildings. The room included all the amenities you could need, including a small fridge, electric kettle, single cup coffee maker, hair dryer, and pants press. The bathroom also contained many single-use convenience items like toothbrushes/toothpaste, cotton swabs, hair comb, razor, etc. The glass-enclosed shower was large and contained a multi-function shower (overhead shower, body spray, or hand-held wand) with excellent water pressure. The wifi was a little finicky, where I'd have to force my iPad to "forget" the network so I could log in again to get it to work, but that was usually limited to once a day, and it was speedy the rest of the time.I would like to give extra praise to the hotel staff. When Typhoon Hagibis hit, everyone in the hotel was very helpful in answering questions. They communicated when they weren't able to have room service or have housekeeping come around (though you could always call the front desk for extra towels or other items). And the 7-11 in the lobby was perfect for grabbing food and water in case anything happened. In the end, the hotel never lost power, and the food I grabbed at 7-11 saved me as most everything nearby shut down by 1pm on Saturday and didn't open for 24 hours. I would definitely stay at this hotel again, though hopefully next time without a typhoon!

We traveled as a family of 6 for the World Cup in Japan. This was our second port of call in Japan having traveled up from Osaka. We had 2 rooms booked but decided a third would be needed. We asked for a price for the third room and were given it. We decided to look on other booking sites before deciding. We found a room in the hotel on Booking.com for a much lower price than we had just been offered by the hotel. We asked if they would match the Booking.com offer and they said NO.....No movement on price at all. So, we found ourselves in the position of my wife checking in to our 2 previously booked rooms will I sat down at reception and booked another room on my phone. We weren't looking for it to be cheaper than Booking.com and realistically if the hotel had have made a reasonable offer we would have taken the room directly from them but nope...The guy seemed to be senior and the other staff seemed a bit taken aback by his decision but there you go. To the hotel so....Lobby is on the 3rd floor, plenty of bars and restaurants in and around the building. A very good 7/11 on ground floor.Fine big rooms, good views, very comfortable. Staff very friendly and helpful except for our friend on reception. Metro station is one minute away. Plenty to see and do. Overall a very pleasant stay in a very nice property.

Ok hotel!We were a group of travelers. We stayed three nights. It was comfortable and satisfactory. The stuff was nice and attentive. The breakfast was excellent, in verity and taste.The room was tiny in terms of size and height. The decor in the room and in the public areas was absolutely outdated and need renovation. Overall, a reasonable place to stay Tokyo.

Stayed here for 2 nights on a business trip. The single room was very small however it was clean and modern. Great location across the road from the subway and good breakfast buffet. Unusual reception area which is located on the 3rd floor however this works well as you don't have people coming in off the street.

I was continuing my bussines trip to Tokyo after Osaka, and same as last year, I stayed at Akasaka Excel Tokyu Hotel. Overall nothing change for property but change a lot for service which bellow expectation compare with last year.

I booked the least expensive room of this hotel. The room was really small and the double bed, even smaller. Can hardly sleep two people. Of course, the bathroom is small too. Staff were polite but their command of English is limited and this may explain why they do not like to speak too much. Overall, this is an efficient hotel, we were out most of the time and only return to sleep so the small room did not bother us muchAcross the road is a bid electronic shop. Worth a visit. Below this store is the underground train station which made it very convenient. Beside the train station are many shops and restaurants. You will never go hungry here.

Stayed at Akasaka and had comfortable stay - positives were clean room, decent breakfast but there are few improvements areas - one is check in - staff does not care about customer experience and has standard reply to questions - even when rooms are ready they don’t give it on time and when you are tired and come after a long flight the check in experience is not good.

Very nice location.There js a convenience store (7/11) at the ground floor and another across the street (Family Mart and Lawson). You can choose from several restaurants which is also just a short walk across the hotel.The subway metro station is also across the hotel, making it convenient and very easy to get around Central Tokyo.The hotel is also conveniently located within a mall, with Japanese version of Hooters restaurant at the 2nd floor.You may book and take the limousine bus on your way to the airport (Haneda or Narita). The best service I experienced is the way they handled the luggages. Small (soft) luggages are wrapped in plastic bags, especially the backpacks, before loading at the luggage compartment of the bus. Talk about great service.

Rooms and bathrooms and could use some updating. In my first room, there were hairs on my linens and on the bathroom walls. Yeesh. The gym consists of two treadmills, two bikes, a few free weights, and one swiss ball. Bring down your own towel and water because those are not available inside the gym. The breakfast is plentiful, diverse, and very good. The fresh fruit selection is lacking (they serve several types of canned fruit in fruit juices), but the fresh fruit they did have was ripe and delicious. The 7-11 attached to the hotel ended up being more convenient than I had imagined it would be and was great for bringing home various Japanese snacks for friends. Overall a convenient stay.

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel is extremely conveniently located in front of the subway hub station as well as big electronics store. It is also only a few minutes away from one of the most vibrant district of Akasaka with huge varieties of restautant at all levels and prices. The restaurant on the top floor has much variety of ambience and very nice view of Tokyo. It has very good range fo Japanese food. Hotel is served by the airport limousine buses, both serving Haneda and Narita airports. Most highly recommended for both business and sightseeing travelers.
user_name:
eagle32016
New York City, New York

review_body: Excellent location, very neat and clean, friendly staff, reasonably good buffet breakfast, beds and decors are well managed, updated toilet accessories and showers. Restaurants and bars are closer to hotel. Value for money hotel. Beds are big and very comfortable.

Chiyoda area provides a wonderful choice of every description for dining out. While the food within the hotel restaurant was great, like all hotels, eating in can be expensive. Attached to the hotel was a 7/11 shop which provided many alternatives for light dining. Literally across the road from the Metro Rail allowed great access for getting around Tokyo. A MUST is to obtain the Official Tokyo Tourism Guide with an orange cover. This small booklet shows what there is to see in each prefecture, and what trains to catch. A 3 day metro rail pass is about $18 AU (about $12.50 USA). Purchase online before arrival. Head left as you exit the hotel for a Starbucks cafe if coffee is your thing, only 2 minutes walk. The buffet breakfast was excellent, and the staff very helpful, although some of the front desk staff were very limited with English . The only complaint was one I found in all the Japanese Hotels, the pillows were HIDEOUSLY hard. All other amenities within the room were fine. The room was spotless.

Metro station just across the street. Lots of eateries nearby, 7 eleven connected to hotel. Room a little cramped for 3, but i guess this is actually bigger than other tokyo hotels. Service from staff was excellentBreakfast was included with our package, breakfast restaurant was average, and food was the same everyday. Overall would stay here again but without breakfast package since there are alot of eateries nearby

We purchased the room off the hotel search engines and my aim was a large bed as beds in Japan are quite small in comparison to western style. The cheaper room were quite small but adequate with a good bathroom and shower. Breakfast was good. Over the road is akasaka misute subway which was easily accessible from the airport. I would recommend this hotel for a short term stsy( cheap room)

The room was fairly small with an OK queen bed, clock, TV - but only one station in English, but the BBC sometimes in English. Very nice shower. Toilet with a heated seat and automatic flush. Good internet. Breakfast was mainly Asian food. Handy to have the subway nearby (Nagatacho station) and 2 stops to the top of the East Gardens - and then a lovely walk through the parks and around the Imperial Palace.
user_name:
Elga K
Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia

review_body: Great location, train station just opposite our hotel. Nice breakfast. Clean room, even a bit small room size. Mini market just below the hotel, opposite our hotel, just bic camera drug store. Thanks.

Very well located across the street from many restaurants and 20 minutes from parks around Imperial Palace and Chidorigafuchi Park, famous for cherry blossoms. Good rooms with Japanese atmosphere. Noisy though because of the highways, try to get a room away from those... not easy

The first room I got was a single room for one person. It was hot and stuffy and really really tiny. Next day I asked for a twin room. More space and had a sofa. Very little space to hang up my clothes. Good thing I was only there for 3 nights on business. On the upside the service was impeccable. My request to change rooms was dealt with politely and expeditiously. I packed up and was told to leave my bag in the room and staff brought it to the new room for me when I left to attend meetings.The Akasaka Mitsuke station is right across the road. Short subway ride to Shibuya etc. Some restaurants across the road too.

Excel Tokyu Akasaka is well located, opposite the Akasaka Mitsuke metro station. Rooms are average size by Japanese standards. The rooms are well priced, clean and functional. Buffet breakfast is quite good with a good range of western and eastern dishes. This hotel is popular with tourist groups, so the lobby and breakfast can get quite busy at times.

I stayed here for five nights when attending a work conference at a venue nearby. I found the location spot on for my needs. The room as clean and contained everything I required. There was no noise intruding from neighbouring rooms which was a huge plus for me. I would definitely stay here again for business travel.

The hotel is across the street from a metro station. There are two temples nearby as well as the great garden at the New Okani Hotel. A seven-eleven is off the lobby for snacks, drinks and easy meals as well as an atm that takes foreign credit cards. The staff was nice. The breakfast offered buffet style was huge with interesting things not seen in the States-rice, curry, pasta-but also eggs made to order. Our room was small but adequate and there was a bathtub. There is traffic noise from the street below so I wore ear plugs. Strange crunchy pillow which is a Japanese thing but also a soft one. Everything was very clean.

I have been using the Akasaka excel hotel since years and watched it develop from clean and modern to old and not clean. Stains everywhere, dirt on linens and day covers.Still conveniently located but not worth the money any longer. Definitely will make a different choice next time...

I would't pick this hotel if you come just for tourism. Not very near major attractions, but the metro is super close, and since my visit was work related, I enjoyed the stay, all amenities are nice. Small room but they are clean

I enjoy staying there ! I was at floor 8 and rooms mostly are small but having most of hotel equipment that one needs ! Hair dryer , tooth brush , good shower case , electronic toilet, some flat device that do iron job still do not know what exactly it does ,normal breakfast !But for me having access restaurants and bars and tourists places was really convenient !

This hotel in a good location, near train station and food street, close to Sinjuko and Rapongi Room are ok but small but clean and good atmosphere Breakfast just ok have basic things Overall the hotel is good in good price

Conveniently located in facing the metro station Akasaka, it is nice business hotel. If you are American or European travelling with an average luggage, I do not suggest to book the entry level as the rooms are extremely tiny. Book a superior double even you are traveling alone. Breakfast horrible: crowded room with cheap unhealthy food. No Spa or fitness facilities. I do strongly suggest to try a small restaurant located at the Tokyu Plaza, called Kushino Bo Akasaka.

Pleasant, though not massive, room, comfortable bed, small bathroom with odd window into bedroom arrangement - though it did have blinds for privacy!! Had the excellent Japanese toilets! Wonderful idea of a useable smart phone to help with directions and movements around Tokyo. Reasonable breakfasts. All in all a lovely hotel.

It was a winter family trip, two adults and two teens. We reserved two rooms for us. The room wasn't big as a typical hotel in America, but it was sufficient for our use. Beds were comfortable and the room wifi was good. The best part of the hotel were the subway location and the convenience store within the building. The subway station was connected multiple lines, so it was easy to visit various spots in Tokyo without any problem. Also behind the station, there were lots of eateries, shops and convenience stores. Also 7/11 was inside the building, so kids were able to grab any snacks by themselves. We also pulled cash using their ATM once. Staff were extremely pleasant and effective. They spoke decent English, so we didn't have any communication problem. We also used the hotel restaurant for breakfast once. The breakfast was $27 per person and included coffee, juice, tea, Japanese and western style breakfast. It was good good.

The hotel is centrally located with a train station right across the street and multiple shops on the building and across the road. It is a few minutes walk from all the public offices and a couple minutes by train to all the great tourist spots in Tokyo. The rooms are older and it shows particularly in the furniture and the carpet (there are a few non-carpet options available by request) but not badly so. The rooms are tiny compared to US standards but that’s Japan for you. The breakfast was good but pricy and there are multiple food options nearby.

I have stayed at this hotel years ago, and I remember loving it for its location. Akasaka-Mitsuke Station is right across the street from the hotel, and Nagatacho -- which is about a 3-5 minute walk -- has a connecting underground path to the second floor of the hotel. Youu can easily get to Shinjuku, Shibuya, Tokyo Station, and Ikebukuro areas with the Ginza and Marunouchi lines.The hotel itself is great with helpful, polite staff. Their rooms are bigger than some other hotels in Japan, and it comes with plenty amenities. There is a restaurant and their breakfast buffet offers plentiful selections. The American buffet also has a Japanese cuisine section, but you can also opt for a strictly Japanese-only breakfast.Some other great thing about this hotel and its vicinity:- This hotel also is an airport limousine stop, so it gives you easy access to/from Haneda or Narita.- Its vicinity has a lot of restaurants and bars -- some has English menu options.- There is a Don Quijote nearby!

Hotel is well located. Entrance to the Akasaka-mitsuke station is just across the street. Station serves both the Marunouchi (red) and Ginza (yellow) line.Across the street and further down, you can also find a wide variety of Izakayas and Japanese restaurants. If you need late night snacks, there is a 7-eleven on the first floor as well. Food is definitely not a problemReception and breakfast restaurant is on the third floor. Staff is friendly and helpful. The hotel can also help to arrange for limousine bus transfers to both airports (Narita and Haneda) which picks you up from the hotel at the ground floor. Price is reasonable.

Fast effecient serviceA very clean, quiet and pleasant stayRooms are comfortable and staff are very helpful and accommodating Perfectly positioned for the underground to give easy access to all of Tokyo's sights

Located right across the Akasaka-mitsuke station, it is very convenient to travel around Tokyo city. Room was a standard twin with a sofa, with more than enough room for us to open up 2 large luggage bags. I also appreciate the hotel’s effort to go green (Green Coin program) and also the use of refillable toiletries instead of those tiny single use plastic bottles. Many restaurants nearby, convenience stores (Family Mart , 7-11) and a Don Quixote store where you can get almost everything. There is also a Bic Camera store above the station. More of a business hotel, there weren’t as many tourists here which I personally prefer. Would definitely consider this hotel again the next time I visit Tokyo.

The Hotel is situated just the opposite of the airport. You get picked up from the airport in style in a chauffeur driver car although the distance is just a stone throw from the airport. The staff is extremely professional and pleasant and they all speak English.Nice place to unwind after a hectic tour of the day. It's a pick up point for many tour agents.

The hotel is very good located. Close to the metro station. The rooms are clean and nice. The bathroom was also ok. I just stayed for one night with family members from HK. I have to mention that I am born in Europe, so I have different standards. The breakfast was an international buffet. So for all guests who miss eating a croissant or something from Europe are welcome I would recommend the hotel.

The hotel is not a luxury hotel but the room was neat and clean. There were many Japanese guests so the breakfast had typical Japanese food which was a good experience for me. It’s not at shopping area but surrounded by many restaurants. JR station is nearby, so convenient.

The Akasaka Excel is a large hotel situated across the street from a multi-story duty free store and an entertainment district. The hotel staff was attentive, although my almost non-existent Japanese made some interactions challenging. The lobby of the hotel is on the third floor and my room was located almost at the end of the hallway on the ninth floor which is a long hike from the elevator.Like most of the hotel rooms I experienced in Japan, it was a little on the small side in comparison to U.S. hotels. The bathroom, although small, had a deep soaking tub - which worked for me because I'm not tall. They also had one of the Toto high-tech toilets which was a blast - pun intended. The amenities package was overwhelming - toothbrush with mini-toothpaste, razor, comb, brush, hair ties, make-up removers, Q tips and probably other things which I have forgotten.There is a Tully's Coffee on street level a few doors down from the hotel entrance - kind of provided a home-away-from-home feeling. I bought a suitcase for a good price at the store across the street so I could avoid overweight charges on the airline. The entertainment district across the street was fun - lots of restaurants, karaoke places and a cat cafe. Can't beat a Cat Cafe if you're suffering pet withdrawal. There is a large temple - the Sanno Hie Jinja - a few blocks away on the same side of the street as the hotel. The shrine was originally built in the 14th century, but the present shrine was constructed in 1958 after the prior shrine was burnt down in a 1945 air raid.My main complaint was that I couldn't figure out the air conditioning controls and had to open the window to get some air circulation - along with lots of traffic noise. The buffet breakfast provided lots of choice. I'd stay at the hotel again.

kenmore, wa, United States

review_body: The location of this hotel is good. There is a convenience store at the bottom of the hotel and the tube station is only across the road. There are lots of good restaurants, so food wasn’t a problem. There is no shopping mall or department stores nearby. The room was small as expected in Tokyo.Important note:We stayed in the 4/F and the minute we got into the room, we were greeted with a strange smell. When we entered the toilet, the smell was worst. It smelled like public toilet. We asked the hotel to deodorise the toilet, and the smell was still there after. I did not enjoy my stay there and will not stay in this hotel again.

The hotel reception and housekeeping services are acceptable. The rooms are comfortable although a little smaller coompared to those we stated in this trip. However, I do not understand why buffet tables are generally only cleared by staff in Japan after the customers left the restaurant (e.g. in Akasaka Square Dining Restuarant) I can clear the used cups and trays myself during the buffet meals but there are is tray return station in the restaurant.The hotel lobby is convenient connected to several F&B outlets and restaurants. You can also find food opposite the hotel, which is next to the metro station. However, I find shopping options limited.

This hotel is not for this todays period. Small rooms, small fitness, ....I had the feeling I was in the 80s, where building space needed to be exploited as much as possible. The breakfast was not bad though and the service of the people was impeccable. But for more or less the same price you can have the experience of the New Otani, which is around the corner and fully equipped...

Stayed at this hotel for four days and have no complaints. We had a room with two twin beds facing the busy street. Noise wasnt much of an issue for us but the occasional siren would go by. The room is small compared to US standards but not for Japan. There is a nice sized closet that we kept our bags in to keep them out of the way. In comparison, we had a room in Kobe with no closet, so that when we opened our bags we couldn't walk at all.Room was clean. Beds were nice. They have a couple pillows on the bed. One felt like it was stuffed with plastic beads which we thought was a little different. But very usable. The window set up was nice. They had the black out drapes, then a light filter slider which was nice for privacy but allowed light thru. If you opened up the slider then the window also opened up which was nice to get fresh air in. They provided everything you could need in the room - toothbrush/toothpaste, razors, q-tips, hair bands, liquid shampoo and body wash. The room has a safe, refrigerator, and two bottles of water were provided everyday. They also had the "handy" phone which is very nice. Our phones ran hot and cold, but the handy phone could be taken out with you and meant that you always had Google maps and could download apps - like at the Imperial Palace to allow a self guided tour. Also, free international calling but found it only worked to phone land lines not other cell phones.Staff assisted us with reservations at a cafe. Conveniently, the bus to the international airports stops right there several times a day, and is only a few dollars more than navigating the subways. 7-11 is right down stairs.The subway station is right across the street which is handy. If you you go past the subway station, west, you are into a "quieter" neighborhood. The staff provided us with a list of their recommended ramen restaurants. We did not get their breakfast package because of the price, but it is offered. Downstairs is a coffee shop but we also found the McDonalds :-) about 5 minutes away.In summary, if you want a very accommodating, service oriented with no surprises hotel, this would fit the bill. Staff spoke English. The hotel feels like you are in a chain hotel that could be anywhere in the world, which may be exactly what you are looking for. If you are looking for something with a "local" feel this isn't it. Sometimes traveling can be stressful - it was nice to relax comfortably in the hotel after a fun, long day of sightseeing.

I was part of a tour group and so this hotel was included as part of the package. Upon reading on the location of the place before coming to Japan I thought it would be out of the way from the major locations but I was surprised. It's right opposite a subway station and another is around the corner on a different train line. There are plenty of places to eat around and the hotel buffet breakfasts are very extensive. The rooms are a good size and not too small.

Stayed at this hotel for its location and it was really convenient just cross the road to the Metro train entrance. There are a lot of convenience stores such as Lawson, family mart and 7-11 is at the hotel 1st floor. There is a mini hyper-mart 1-Street across the hotel where we can get local snacks, and Japanese household products. Down the street from this hypermart there is a ¥100 store on 2nd floor. Great for last minute shopping or gifts to buy home. Food wise plenty of options from Budget or good restaurants behind the metro building. Room wise it’s reasonable size, big enough to open a 26’ luggage for packing. Love the bath tub and hair dryer is not those attached wall type which is good.

The Akasaka Excel Tokyu rooms are bigger than many hotels in the Akasaka area. Definitely a bigger than the Centurion & APA Villa variety and doesn’t leave you feeling claustrophobic. It is however much smaller than the ANA Intercontinental, Okura or New Otani. The room is clean and so is the washroom. They have free wifi and a mobile phone that you can carry with you while traveling - giving you free wifi, unlimited free local calls and unlimited free international calls to 6 countries including China, Usa, UK etc. Quite a neat addition. I also like that the prompt lifts take you straight from the hustle bustle of the streets (level 1) to your room without the hotel lobby (which is at level 3) interfering with your hurry to reach your room. I didn't have a breakfast option when I booked on Agoda - so no comments there. The wifi was okay and seamless.

The title of the review says it all; three reasons why this hotel is a good place to stay especially for first-timers. Yes, the rooms are small but not unusually so for a Tokyo hotel. It is slightly more expensive than the other hotels in the area, but not by much. And the hospitality service has the usual high Japanese standards. But the main reason why this hotel is such a good choice is that it is the best hotel near Akasakamitsuke station, a well-known crossing point for the two oldest subway lines, the Marunouchi and the Ginza lines. These two lines allow you to get to all the major Tokyo districts of interest by just using one line (no changes) -- Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ginza, Tokyo, Ueno, Asakusa, and Ikebukuro. Add to that, there are great restaurants covering all tastes and budgets in the main Akasaka district just across the street. Plus the hotel is major enough to be one of the Limousine Bus stops, handy for those with a bit too much luggage to lug around the subway. On another trip to Tokyo, you may want to stay in your favourite district, but for me, the convenience of being next to Akasakamitsuke station beats out all other locations.

We were fulfilling our Lifelong dream to see the cherry blossom in Japan. We joined A group from the UK and were booked to stay in this hotel. Located In the middle of town, perfect for walking to shops and restaurants. A buzzing area.The hotel is very run down, small rooms with no curtains, instead the window is wall papered and sliding , which allows very little light in. The glass window is fixed and can not be moved. It felt very uncomfortable being in the room measuring 4x5 meters. Nights were hot and uncomfortable and the air-condition could not be lowered for some reason. The bed was small and uncomfortable and the pillows were stuffed with what seemed like beads or grains. There was no way of finding out. Towels were small and flimsy.Staff hardly spoke or understood English.Breakfast was mostly Japanese food with few international edible foods. The que for breakfast can be long and on the first morning had to wait 20 minutes to be seated. We ended spending most of our time outside and came back only to sleep .

Excellent location with very short walk to metro with different lines. Spacious for 3 pax in a room which is surprise for Japan hotels. Easy access from airport via bus limousine and they have a counter at hotel for return to airport as well which makes reservation an ease.

With Tokyo being so spread out and relatively costly, choosing a hotel with a convenient location at the right price is essential. This was our first stay at Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu and we were delighted with the location, service, rooms and the excellent buffet breakfast. It was a great choice and worth the price we paid compared to other similar options.

The hotel offered a comfortable room with great amenities (in room coffee and tea, nice shampoos and body wash). The breakfast buffet was delicious and had many choices from local cuisine to Western options. My bed was comfortable but I heard a lot of noise from the street. It was convenient to have the Narayan airport bus available right from the hotel. I would recommend to business travelers.

This is my third stay in this hotel. It’s a good hotel with a great location as it is easy to go everywhere from the local metro. There is only one bad thing, no sound insulation in the door, it’s so poor it’s like there is no door at all. When other guests walk by and talk normally it’s like they stand beside you and you really think if you have closed the door. If you are okay with this then it is a good hotel with a perfect location.

Facing the Tokyo metro station, easy access, not far from Ginza and close to shops, restaurants and pubs (walking distance). Small but comfortable rooms, excellent choice of restaurants nearby, friendly and helpful staff. Loved staying there.

The hotel is very near to restaurants, shopping places, local attractions & etc. All are within walking distance. Love the convenience store located just below the hotel! Not to forget the duty free shopping BIC which just across the road! Don't forget to check this out! Feel free to visit each floor! Lastly, let my breakfau7st photos tell you the story...

I have stayed at this hotel several times now. First with the not so good, the rooms themselves are not the lure to stay here. Rooms are old but clean and have everything you need. Typical small business hotel type rooms with not so good air circulation, you will notice the stale air right away when you enter your room. Having said that, there are many Pros to this place. Location, location, location. It is right across the street from the subway, plenty of restaurants and shopping. The service at this hotel is also fantastic. The breakfast spread is quite impressive and has the western or Japanese option. There will be something for everyone. Lastly, the Airport Limousine stops at the front door which makes things very convenient! I will be back.

Convenient location, I stayed there comfortably for 5 days. The only complaint was that the windows could not open, and there was only warm air circulation in window in the hotel. This made the room a bit too warm and stuffy.

Arrived in Japan from Manchester Via Qatar on the 8th of October and stayed at the Akasaka from the 8th until the 11th October, although the room was clean and tidy with a comfortable enough bed this was by far the smallest room I have ever stayed in, I don't think I even had a window.The location was good and I believe there is/was a mini market on the ground floor of the hotel where you can get noodles and Sake, on the first night being jet lagged and excited to of arrived I drank most of if not all of that bottle of Sake and mixed it with Ciroc which I had carried from England, I haven't drank Sake since.

In hindsight reviewing the five hotels we experienced in Japan, Excel's rating gets a boost. And it's all because of the location. The hotel is located in Akasaka which is really the ideal place to stay when in Tokyo if you want to be close enough to take a very short train ride (on a direct line) to the key areas, and walking distance to an array of great restaurants. The hotel is literally across the road from Akasaka Mitsuke station and it's incredibly convenient.The hotel itself is quite lovely (on the inside, maybe a little 'practically designed' on the outside), you don't really see the staff as the foyer is not on the ground floor. The room we had on the 10th floor was relatively small (especially compared to Hotel New Otani which is arguably much fancier and cost the same), and as a result there was limited storage space and the bathroom was truly TINY. The bathroom door got in your way when you're at the sink to give you an idea.You did get a Nespresso machine though and a Handy free-wifi phone which is great. And the bed was excellent, just the right firmness. I got a great nights sleep here, it was actually hard getting up.I'm increasing the rating for the hotel purely for the location, otherwise the small room and tiny bathroom would have brought it down (for the price).

My husband and I have stayed in this hotel several times in the last 10 years. While the room bathroom sizes are comparatively small, they are comfortable and clean. The bed is very comfortable. It is in a great location with all local transport alternatives within a 5 minute walk. Plenty of eating places in all price ranges near by. The hotel itself has a great restaurant where the food is excellent. The airport bus services this hotel from Narita. I recommend this hotel and the pricing for a city like Tokyo very reasonable in a safe neighborhood.

Location is walking distance to so many shops and is just right across one of the biggest Bic Camera stores in tokyo wc has everything from bikes, cameras, laptops to cosmetics. There are numerous restos also in the area from fastfoods to ramen shops. In the hotel building arcade itself, you can go to hooters or starbucks. The rooms are small wc is typical of tokyo hotels however it is very complete. This hotel offers you many amenities in the room. The beds are so nice to sleep in. The sleeping robe is very soft and i used it every night. There is even a 7-11 convenience store in the ground floor and a train subway just across. Definitely one of my favorite hotels in tokyo.

I chose this hotel because it is near to city center. The room is pretty tidy when we arrived, though it looks pretty old, but good enough for our stay. It provides a handy phone with free data and calls, though it is pretty slow and sometime the camera won’t work.The staff are very friendly, the concierge has even spend sometime with me to troubleshoot my transport back to airport by looking at the various options.The hotel has nearby train station and also lots of good foods, restaurant and bars. It is just 4 stops away to ginza, about 10 stops away to asakusa, and so on.I will definitely consider it again when i am in tokyo city.

Stayed here for 4 days for business trip on November 2017, nearby train station akasaka mitsuke maybe walking around 100 meters. From Haneda / Narita Airport, you can drop in front of this hotel and returned. For all moslems. there are little options for breakfast but it's okay, because there is seven eleven on ground floor. In this hotel, you can easily leaving your luggage here, even you already left by this hotel. But 1 minus thing from this hotel is there is no air conditioner, so the solution from room service is I had to open the window like every single night

Travelling on holiday as a family of 3, we thought it was a good price considering this is a 4 stars hotel, and it certainly looked that way seeing the exterior and foyer of the hotel; however we shouldn’t have judged a book by its cover… Location – Brilliant location for shuttle bus drop off/pick up as it’s right in front of the hotel. The metro station and the heart of Asakasa is just a stone throw away, divided by a main road/foot bridge. Having said that, this is also a negative as you do receive a considerable amount of traffic noise during peak hours. Luckily the traffic does die down at night (unless police/ ambulance decides to whiz pass the hotel) Corridor – The corridor (approx. 100m in length) runs the full length of the hotel with a main lifts foyer in the middle. If your room is close to the lifts foyer, it can get noisy; but if your room is at the end of the corridor, it’s a long walk to the lift… choose your room location wisely. Room – Reasonably sized by the Japanese standard, not big and just enough room to place your luggage. Considering the size of the room, it’s probably adequate for business traveller but I can’t say the same for our 4yo. There’s not much character to the room and it feels a bit dated considering how grand the foyer is. Don’t expect too much as it’s just a standard room – 4 walls, small TV (no English channel) and a large window facing the main road. For the very least, the room is clean. Check in/Check out – Super fast and effortless. Having said that, do expect a long queue at the time of check out. Service – In typical Japanese fashion, everyone (but one) was super nice and really helpful, most speak English which is handy. We did endure an incident with the man-in-charge (the manager, maybe?) at the porter area whereby we wanted to use the scale to weight our luggage at the waiting area (no traffic and less than 5 metres from the porter area). Not only was the man super rude and inflexible, he would not let us use the scale unless it is 1 metre within the porter area – this proved to be extremely inconvenient given that the porter area was within a high traffic area. In the end, we had to move our luggage one piece by one piece (between the waiting area and the porter area) and battle the traffic to weight our luggage. Despite the bitter experience, some of the (female) staff did offer to help (move our luggage) which was nice of them. 7-Eleven – Located on the ground floor, this proved very handy for snack.

Stayed here just recently for 3 nights for business and I must say, its a great hotel. the location is bang opposite Akasaka Mitsuke metro station, which has connectivity to everywhere in Tokyo. The Akasaka area is amazing for food and hence, one will find no problem at all finding good food, not just Japanese, but even other cuisines. the downsides are that the rooms might be considered small, but I guess that's what Japan offers in such types of hotels. There is no fitness center, which might be a bummer for people who like to workout. The staff can tend to be not aware of the surrounding areas, but they do try to help. Overall, very good hotel with good connectivity to Shinjuku, Tokyo station and other main attractions in Tokyo.

Stayed at this hotel for three nights in early September. Comfortable hotel with a good mix of breakfast options. As with most Japanese hotels rooms are on the small size but comfortable. Hotel is in a good location for getting around Tokyo with many restaurants in the area. Japanese and western buffet for breakfast. Free internet. Good location from metro to get around Tokyo.

We stayed here for four nights on a recent trip to Japan. The hotel was comfortable. Over the road were dozens of restaurants to choose from as well as two train lines, so it was easy to get around from. The airport limousine bus service drops you right at the hotel which was an added bonus after 24 hours of travel to get there.

Love the location of this hotel. Staff is friendly and very helpful. this is the third time I have stayed here and service is consistent. Location is great for evening dining. Not only is this hotel located close by to train and amazing dining but it also offers bus service (for a fee) to Narita or Haneda Airport.

Personally I like Akasaka a lot because this area is close to everywhere in Tokyo. It is easy to head west to Shinjuku or head east to Tokyo Station area. And, Hotel Excel is just right next to the Metro Station so that it is super convenient. Despite the fact that the hotel is not new, the room is still very clean with comfortable air-con. And, the room is large enough for a couple to put 2 luggages in! :)

Again a fantastic experience! We first stayed here in 11/2015 and now again in 5/2017; and both experiences were 1st rate! When we travel to Tokyo, we love to stay in Akasaka, and this is the best spot.Predominately, a business hotel, the area is quiet and feels a bit like San Francisco. With green areas nearby, street upon street of restaurants, and high rise office buildings we felt right at home. It’s a great home base for seeing this side of Tokyo, and it eases you into Tokyo life at a slower pace than Shinjuku. The metro and buses are just steps away. The room sizes are large by Japanese standards, and very comfortable. We especially like the superior double, it has a bit more space and well worth the little extra cost. There are restaurants in the lobby, but you’d be better off going out to the terrace restaurants or across the street, where there are tons of places to eat.The bed is very comfortable and the style of the rooms is light and airy with modern zen overtones. And if you choose a room with a tub, you will definitely feel as if you have had a true Japanese experience. We will always stay here when in Tokyo!

The hotel seemed to be located in a very safety and convenient area.You would see a lot of government office buildings, foreign ambassy buildings near the hotel. You can also see many people running in the morning alongside the buildings.Across the hotel, there are lots of restaurant, pubs and convenient stores that you can enjoy a variety of food late night. The hotel can be easily access using subway lines and it provides a great breakfast buffet.

It is in the centre of Tokyo, Akasaka, so it is easy access to all the sightseeing place. But there is not so much shopping area near the hotel. Only one Bic Camera and one drug store. The room is clean and comfortable. The front desk can help to reserve the limousine bus for airport transfer.

Got a smoking room instead of a non smoking as checked in earlier than scheduled time. room was reeking of smoke smell and i used up an entire bottle of freshener and opened up the window and door to let fresh air in. excellent location for trains, shopping, restaurants, bars. standard twin bed room on line I got faced the main street (opp BIC Camera) noisy and west facing. if summer, one would not be able to sleep as the room would b an oven as the central air con is not really strong enough. male concierge staff (elderly ones) are absolutely flower vases not lifting a finger to anyone with bags but the young female staff are very friendly indeed. this hotel does not allow guests to leave bags prior to check in so do take note or you get a nasty look when you insist. this is also one hotel who does not bother to apologise to guests standing for the airport limo when the bus was 10 mins late; no managing of expectations unlike other hotels I have stayed in. thus a hotel with excellent location is marred by the elderly veteran staff who are no longer service oriented. Retraining absolutely required but if you are like I who use hotel only for sleeping, then go for this hotel.

Excelent service, very helpful staffs, and close to interesting places. The ambience is nice, clean. The Restaurant buffet is delicious, my family enjoyed very much.Neat and nice rooms.Over all, it is an excellent hotel to pick for business and leisure as well.

This hotel is in an excellent location just across the road from the subway station which can get you almost anywhere in Tokyo. The rooms are relatively quiet even though there's a busy road out front. Staff are very polite and helpful at all times. Rooms are quite small but contain all the facilities you need. An excellent breakfast is served on the third floor. English is spoken quite well by most staff who can help you with directions to get to where you want to go. A very good choice.

Perfect location near subway close to the shops nightlife and restaurants convinience store 7-11 downstairs the room was nice and clean ( not huge but well organized) I advise this hotel to stay in Tokyo a great place to stay ❤️

I was here in Tokyo back in 2010 and stayed at the Akasaka Intercontinental and payed lots of money really for nothing . Please believe be the Intercontinental is Luxurious but it lacked in the one on one connection .,Akasaka Excel is way cheaper . I paid $1100 for 7 nights in a room with a king size bed ( and very comfortable ) and about 300sqft. My idea was why pay all this money when I'm not even in the room . Excel offered a professional staff that went way beyond . The hotel is super clean , take that to the bank . No lie ! When I made reservations for the hotel, i had many , many questions . I sent email after email and within 3 hrs had a reply back .. That was impressive to me . and they helped me out immensely, because it wasn't pithy answers but, explanations as well .. Restaurant and buffet is pretty good as well . The hotel sits within walking distance of Akasaka subway. The hotel doesn't provide a gym . They do offer a discounted program at a gym located in the Prudential Tower which is a 3 minute walk . The price for the week was $62 . I figured compared to the states that's about normal . Give this hotel a second look . They do work for you .

Pros: - Very comfortable beds and linen, pillows just right - Decent-sized rooms (for Japan). My single room was about 19 sq.m.- Great amenities (shampoo, conditioner, and body soap are in large refillable bottles; no fiddling with tiny plastic bottles!) - Great breakfast buffet with Western and Japanese options - Excellent location just across Akasaka-mitsuke station; lots of restaurants in the hotel building itself with a 7-11, and more across the street - Attentive staff who speak pretty good English (although one person at the front desk NEVER smiled at me or said thank you when I checked in and out. And I spoke Japanese with her the whole time! Very unusual for Japanese hotel staff who are usually so courteous. Needs to take a refresher course on customer service!- Currency exchange machine right in the lobby Cons: - Linear layout means you can end up walking a long way from the elevator to your room if you don't ask for one closer. This was very inconvenient on the first night for my dad who can't walk that far. - Room interiors a bit dated - Can be noisy as it's very popular with Asian tour groups- Their "business center" is just an outdated coin PC in the lobby with a tiny workstation and a very uncomfortable chair. Overall, pretty good experience and would likely stay here again.

Located just across the road of Akasaka-Mitsuke / Nagatacho metro stations, easy to commute to any part of Tokyo; 18 minutes to Ueno and 9 minutes to Shinjuku. Airport limousine bus stops right in front of the hotel, very convenient if you have big luggage. Food choices is plenty across the road or next to the Akasaka-Mitsule station. The hotel double bedroom was comfortable with generous amenities, staff is professional and friendly.

Tee Wee J
Hong Kong, China

review_body: Booked a standard room. Weather was cold at 12degrees celsius but room was hot. Aircon cannot function well and no windows to open for fresh air.Spoke with reception and was told that hotel was old thus most rooms aircon were this way. Need to open window if we want cooler temperature. We need to top up extra money to upgrade to Superior room for a window that can be open. Told us they is a fan where we can use if too warm.We decided not to change the room as we hardly stayed in. Fan instructions all in Japanese so we tried our best to operate it. Conclusion - room still v warm.Despite the set back above, we enjoyed our 6 days stay there. Dated room, A4 size foldable mirror, coffee machine etc all provided. Room is small its ok. Staff do their job n apologetic if things gets out of hand. Guess the best selling point of this hotel is its location. The airport limousine bus stop is here where we can book tickets via staff. Took only 35mins to reach airport in our sunday 8pm departure. MRT/Subway lines- hotel located in the middle of city. There are at least few lines serving there to different parts of Tokyo.My advice-book a room with window that can be opened and avoid summer. Honestly, I will rate 5 stars if rooms look new n aircon works well.

Akasaka Excel is part of a chain found in major cities of Japan and offers very good hotel services and all the comforts a traveller would normally seek at competitive prices . Their breakfast buffet is a delight with a large variety of dishes catering to different cultures besides Japanese . It is ideally located in the Chiyoda district with major business enterprises as well as restaurants etc located nearby .

Stayed here for 3 nights on a tour and it was a really good, modern hotel with all facilities including a heated toilet seat that flushed automatically! Great location - opposite a metro station and on a main road with a 7/11 in the lobby which was very handy. The rooms were larger than expected and had a large double bed which was surprising as I was travelling solo and usually get a tiny single bed. Staff were very polite and helpful and everyone was very friendly. Highly recommended.

The hotel is conveniently placed next to the Nagatacho underground station, which has links to other underground lines. Rooms are small but clean and have everything you need such as fridge, safe and free WiFi. Reception is on the third floor and this floor also has an elevator which goes down to the second floor and onto an overhead walkway - which is the easiest way to get across the busy street.

Walking distance to train station, shopping mall good selection of restaurants around the area and 7eleven is just down in the lobby. Only stayed overnight so cannot give a compressive review.The room size was bigger than Japanese standard but everything else is normal (small), like the bed, toilet and shower area.The place is clean and the staff are very helpful no problems with communicating in English.Will consider again if need hotel close to the area.

A nice, modern hotel, well located (across from subway station).Food was average, room clean but small. Seven Eleven in building. Nearby restaurants and government buildings. Many of the staff speak English.

New York City, New York

review_body: This is a nice hotel in Tokyo in the Nagatacho area. The rooms are quite good even if mine had not a view on the street and had a window that was not possible to open to change the air. The typical Japanese bathroom and the shower (with Shiseido products) are good enough. The breakfast area is big and with international meals. The reception staff is fast and gentle. You can book (and pay) a shutlle service to the Narita airport (it will cost you less than a taxi if you are less than 4). The Nagatacho metro station is close to the hotel.

Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu is very strategically located 1 minute walk to akasaka train station and many cafes and Japanese authentic restaurants. There is also a good size supermarket across the road behind a huge electronic store called BIC Camera.The rooms are small as in any Japanese hotels but very clean and well maintained.

very impressed! i wanna stay there again when i visit tokyo. the bell captain, front clerk, and restaurant staff were nice and their smile made me relax and happy. i recognize why my boss recommended to stay there. it's not only the good location but also great staff!

Stayed here for a business trip for 3 nights. As others have said, it has nothing but the location going for it. If you are an international traveller, then definitely not the place for you. Cleanliness : Can be much better. There was hair in the toilet bowl and the sheet had some sort of a paint mark on it. The Sofa and footstool are stained and dirty. Coffee maker had dust on it. Room was SMALL. Passable given Tokyo standards. But a small room tucked away at the back with nothing to look out was not pleasant. Breakfast : Same menu two days in a row. Half cooked pasta and french fries for the non meat eaters. Thank god for cereal and bread! Concierge desk speaks no English, so how does one get help about airport transfer? Service is basic so don't expect much.

Long review time! Love this hotel :)Airport limo drops right at the doorstep and lobby is on the 3rd floor. Everything is easily accessible! Subway is just opposite the road and down an escalator.Huge electronics store (Bic Camera) opposite the hotel as well (i'm talking about 7 levels or so). And SO MUCH FOOD & CONVENIENCE STORES at the back. Takoyaki, gyoza, ramen, etc omg i miss this place. There's Don Quixote somewhere down the road too. Just keep walking around and you will find something!There's also alot of karaoke parlours there (karaoke-kan, etc) and pachinko if are into that. Train station there is Akasaka-mitsuke and you can get a pasmo card at the ticket machine (suica has to be bought elsewhere but it doesn't matter much). Easily accessible to all the main spots that tourists usually go. Hotel staff are friendly and they brought up our bags to the room for us as well. Anyway the hotel is part of a mall (Tokyu Plaza) and there's a Saizeriya there at basement 1 (family restaurant) and i ate super cheap escargots everyday hahaha. :') a cafe downstairs as well and a 7-11.TLDR; best hotel i have stayed. Heated toilet seats, convenient, food everywhere, can choose smoking or non-smoking roomPictures: comfy bed, view from room and view of hotel I will definitely book this hotel when i come back to Tokyo again!

OK yes this is a functional hotel. It's not really a luxury hotel. It's not cheap but compared to the rate at say the Intercontinental this was nearly half.Lets start with the room. Yes it small. Very small but it's very comfortable and has everything you need. Its clean and tidy. Not modern but everything worked fine. I actually was very comfortable. I'm a big guy and was fine in this room. the room had a small refrigerator and a Nespresso coffee machine with 4 capsules each day. Nice touch. My room was on the main road side and there was very little noise, except the occasional siren. You could open the window which I liked and the room was completely black with the curtains closed.My only issue was that I ended up in a smoking room. My mistake at booking (I'm not used to hotels allowing smoking anymore). Unfortunately they didn't have a non-smoking double room and I have to say I suffered with the smell. If you are a non-smoker, make sure you check when making the booking that you are getting what you want.Getting to the hotel from Narita was fine. I like the fact that this hotel is on one of the Limousine Bus stops, or you can get there very easily by train. I had to depart early from Haneda and it was a very simple 30 minute taxi ride for about US$60. The location is excellent. It's directly across the road from a massive electronic store (Bic Camera) which keeps any gadget nut like me busy for a few hours. Apart from that there is a huge (I men huge) selection of restaurants and bars in the same building and directly across the street. Simply walk across the street and there are three narrow lane ways each about 300-400metres in length stuffed full of restaurants and bars, many open 24 hours. All of them cater for English speaking visitors. Remember that Tokyo is a 3D city so when looking for a nice place to eat look up, as many of the are on the 3rd or 4th floor.There is a 7-Eleven on the ground floor for everything you need. There are numerous cafe's and restaurants in the place.The service was professional and helpful but not overly so. They provided the information I needed when I asked and gave me enough information to get me where I was going.As for breakfast I would suggest dump the hotel breakfast and go and get something from one of the Cafe's in the building (Tully's Coffee is right there) or across the street. There is a Starbucks about 3-4 mins walk away/The hotel is a very comfortable mid range hotel. Don't expect 5 Star service but expect a working functional clean, safe and well located hotel.Free internet was excellent too!I'd go back.

I know that Tokyo is expensive, but there is so much better than this place for the same money. Let's start with the one good thing: it's clean. I cannot think of any other advantages. The hotel pretends to be a place for business. I guess it is if you're prepared to pay US$250 without breakfast and do away with service, luxury and space. One by one: can you help me to book a train. No, we don't offer that service. Can I eat something small for lunmch, like a sandwich. No sir, we are full for that. Does my room rate include breakfast? No sir, you must buy a ticket in advance (non refundable). Would you have some tomato sauce (ketchup)? No sir, we do not have that in cluded in a $25 breakfast. The room is dark and stuffy and VERY small. The bathroom door is so narrow, that you must enter sideways. My recommendation: go elsewhere.

the hotel is conveniently located and offers variety of room sizes. a bit on expensive side but the location makes up for that.most rooms are small but the amenities and decor are good for a nice and peaceful sleep!breakfast spread/ala carte is nice as well. I liked their service too!

This hotel is well located for business in Tokyo, however, its services are less than I expected. It is a typical Japanese business hotel. The rooms are small, the bathroom small, and no English language TV whatsoever.In room wifi was good. Although I had paid for 5 nights in advance when I arrived a little early I was advised my room was available but I would need to pay the full rack rate for an early arrival. I refused and returned later to be advised the room was not then available and then I was given a very poor room at the back of the hotel, with a very small window looking out on a concrete wall. It was however possible to open the window and the room was quiet.The hotel is across the road from the metro and there are numerous restaurants within easy walking. The hotel is very Japanese with few western guests.Not recommended.

The room was the smallest I have ever been in but it was fantastic. Comfortable bed and pillows and really quiet room. No noise to wake up a jet-lagged traveller. None. Functional bathroom, a toilet for the ultra geek who loves comfort. The service at the hotel was superb and all staff made an effort to speak English. The breakfast buffet was both western and Japanese. The western half was good. And lastly, the location is great.

Stayed there with wife and 11yo daughter for 5 nights. Before we arrived, we sent them a few emails to ask them to help us book restaurants but it was a waste of time as they never got back to us even after emails and phone calls. So we made the bookings ourselves. When we arrived, the staff helped us to book and confirm when we asked. The rooms are so small that you can't really fully open your suitcases and have to store them in the closet when we are in the room, otherwise there is no space to move around. The air conditioner, I was told, cannot be fully turnoff and will always give out warm air, never cold. Since the duvet was also "heavy duty", we have to open the windows at night to go to sleep. But the area has a very vibrant nightlife so if you are a light sleeper, ear plugs are needed. But location is great with 4 lines within 15 min walk and many small bars and restaurants to sample. Breakfast and sauna is included but didn't try the latter. Breakfast is basic so you can skip and venture out to try other things if needed. Next time I would stay in the same area but another hotel.

Room are two thumbs up due to its spaciousness. Services are excellent with staff goes over and above. Location can't get much better with the Tokyo Metro station being right across the street. We didn't try the restaurants within the hotel complex since the Akasaka back streets are just a block away with plenty of local favors.

Location is great. Easy to access Sunway lines, and you can take limousine from hotel to airport. Very convenient! Room is comfortable, although a bit old. Room size is decent especially when other Japanese hotel normally has small rooms. The famous Ninja Restaurant is just downstairs.

First time to stay in Akasaka Excel hotel Tokyu and it's very convenient for our family with 3 kids ages 11, 10 and 7, plus my mother in law who's 73 years old. Easy access to the subway station just under the hotel or you can cross the street just right under the mall Bic Camera. Conveniently located even though it's a business district, 15 mins away from the Imperial Palace. Just across our hotel there are small alleys that has small restaurants and shops that sells food, clothing, accessories and shoes even around 1 in the morning. The room is not too big but not too small and clean. They change your towels and slippers on a daily basis. This hotel is located in Akasaka Mitsuke station and connected to the Nagatacho station if you need to change lines.

Stayed for four nights for business. Nice, clean, professional hotel. Nothing fancy. Staff seemed professional and attentive. Great location directly across street from Metro station and Akasaka entertainment district.Rooms were small-ish yet typical for a Tokyo area hotel. Bathroom was VERY small to point of discomfort.Breakfast buffet was just OK.The rooms facing the road are VERY noisy. Especially as the A/C was off for the season resulting in a hot and stuffy room. Only way to cool off the room was to open the window and deal with the noise.No english-language TV stations but the nespresso coffee maker was nice.

A nice hotel. Its honest in that Its not trying to be flashy and bespoke, it is small, clean hotel with a comfortable bed in the middle of Akasaka. If you are looking for reasonably priced clean hotel and you are in Tokyo for a few days like I was, then this is ok. On the down side - I had a room with two single beds which was not ideal, you couldn't swing a cat in the bathroom / toilet and the breakfast fare was adequate and ok but fairly limited.It certainly won't be my first choice next time I travel to Tokyo but I would be happy here if my other choices were not available

Being in Tokyo for the first time, I am pleased with my choice of hotel. Located along the busy Ginza Metro line that stretches from the historic Asakusa to the vibrant Shibuya, I found the location ideal for my six days stay. There is also non-stop action opposite the hotel, where the Metro station is located. Besides the location and convenience of the Metro, there is always a ready line of taxis just by the ground floor entrance to the hotel. The hotel facilities are above expectations for a hotel of this standard. Amenities are generously provided. The front line personnel are professional and there is even a convenient money-changing machine at the lobby. Every morning as I leave my room, I see the efficiency and the friendliness of the housekeeping staff at work. Overall, two thumbs up!

I stayed for 3 nights. Rooms are quite reasonably large (for Tokyo). Quiet place if you are not on the road side (ask). Classic, clean, etc... The place all around has everything you need (restaurants,...).

Clean well located for business, very near to metro station.Extremely tiny room however had almost everything except a safe. Average breakfast quality.If the location is important, it's recommended otherwise there is plenty of better hotels.

This hotel is an adequate business Hotel with a wonderful location. It is across the street from a metro station where two Metro lines come together. This means you can get almost anywhere you want in Tokyo easily. It is also a five-minute walk from the New Otani Hotel, which is a great place to go for a Splurge meal or to enjoy their beautiful gardens and interior.I had a solo room which was small but adequate. The beds are comfortable, there is a TV and a small bathroom with tub / shower. My one disappointment was that the hotel advertised Nespresso machines in each room and I was disappointed to find out that that was not true for the solo rooms. I offered to rent a Nespresso machine but was told no. I am not sure why this was impossible since I had offered to pay rent on the machine.Across the street from this hotel are myriad restaurants , most of them quite good with great variety. You can find sushi, okonomiyaki, takoyaki, tempura Etc as well as Spanish, Italian, Turkis, German and a great Oyster Bar. Just a few doors down from the hotel is a Tully's Coffee where you can get a very decent latte and pastry and sandwiches.If I return to Tokyo I will definitely stay in Akasaka because it is a great base for exploration. However next time, I will most likely book at the New Otani :-)

This hotel is in a great location--walking distance to the Imperial palace, across the street from many great rstaurants and the Akasaka-mitsuke metro station. This station services many lines so you can be in all tourist areas within 10min.The wifi works great, staff is extremely helpful. Bus to Narita and Haneda airport stops right in front of the hotel and you can purchase tickets from concierge.

A great hotel centrally located to the train stations and a short walk to the shops and restaurants Just on the main shopping street & the rooms are comfortable and clean.Great spot to stay , they have English maps of the town every one is extremely friendly

Excellent hotel with many good restaurants nearby and very convenient for trains. Rooms are reasonable size for Tokyo standards, clean and nice view over park/trees (on one side only). Great restaurants in-house as well.

Pleasantly surprised by this hotel in the Akasaka area. Rooms are a little bit small but comfortable, updated, and well maintained like most Japanese hotels. Hotel is located inside a mall and closed to interesting foodie restaurants, markets, and a popular temple where tourists and locals go. Great view from the lookout lounge on the upper floor of the hotel. Friendly front desk and close to metro stations. Recommend for the budget travelers away from busy central Tokyo.

First of all, the room was not clean, and old. There was dust in every corners of the carpet. The paint on the furniture was coming off. And the worst part, there were yellow marks (water stains or something worse?) on the bathroom walls. You can see them in the photos.Secondly, the amenity were below average. Before this I stayed at Super Hotel LOHAS Tokyo Station Yaesu Chuo-guchi and it was much cheaper with much better room (smaller but cleaner) and amenity. The bed is ok, but in the middle of the night the speaker on the desk started to make static noise and we had to unplug it. It was not a pleasant experience after a long day.Lastly, we booked this hotel with the expectation that it has coin laundry machines. I booked directly on their website and under the list of facilities there is a link for "More Details". After clicking into it, you can see "coin laundry" clearly listed under the Facilities section. Screen caps attached. Or you can visit their website directly.However, when we arrived, we were told there was no coin laundry. When I showed the staff the website, he was confused as well, and said it must be a mistake because they have never had coin laundry, but only laundry service (which was very expensive). I asked if we can get compensated because of their false advertisement, and he said he would get back to me. Half an hour later he called our room and said we were the one mistaken, that the list of Facilities were just "possible facilities", and only the icon in the previous page (before I click the "More Details" link) were the facilities actually offered.Ok, I suppose that is an explanation, that I have misinterpret the website. But why not make the website more clear? Why name the link "More Detail" as if suggesting that there were more facilities? Why not make it clear which facilities were actually offered, and which ones were not? And why would their own staff be confused when he first looked at the website???When I presented these question to them, all they did were apologizing. No actual action were taken even though the staff admitted that the website was confusing. I'm not just complaining about the service because of this incident. I stayed at 3 other hotels during my trip, and every one of them offer better customer service than this one. They were more accommodating, caring, and valued your business. They gave you warm greetings when you walked in and out of the hotel. Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu offered none of these. They just did the very basic and wanted you to get our of their way. For a big hotel chain I expect them to have better maintained rooms, better customer service, and offer some kind of compensation for falsely, or at least, confusingly, listed facilities they do not actually offer. However, there is not even a comment/complaint section on their website. This alone tells you how much they care about their customers.I seriously recommend you staying away from this hotel. If you are looking for a location close to train stations, go with Super Hotel LOHAS Tokyo Station Yaesu Chuo-guchi. It's a 3 min walk from Tokyo Station, and it's much cheaper and better than this place.

There are 4 Tokyo Metro lines next to the hotel making it really easy to get to most locations across the city. The hotel itself is great, like most Japanese hotel rooms they are not huge but they are comfortable

I have just returned from Tokyo after spending about 10 days at this hotel. Great location right across from Akasaka-mitsuke metro station. The service was excellent and Wi-Fi worked well in the room and lobby. I was pleasantly surprised to the moderate single room I reserved. My room was spacious; on 12th floor facing the back of the hotel; and the first room off the elevator. The view from the room was many trees and it was very quiet. I had heard that the rooms in this hotel were very small but the moderate single room I had was perfect for me. Next time I go to Tokyo, I would consider staying at this hotel again.

It located in great location which opposite Big Camera Mall. There are Asakasa stations around hotel only walk few minutes. All staffs have good English, good food, good service, wider room than most hotel.

The hotel is located in a building with shops on the first two floors, reception is on the third floor. Reception staff are efficient and speak English. Besides the reception is a counter to buy tickets for the Narita airport bus, and some samples of souvenirs that can be bought in shops located elsewhere in the building. Nice ceramics! The room was small (as is common in Japan) but well equipped with a place to work and a single bed (comfortable). Lighting was good and the air con efficient, and little noise was heard from outside. Space to place a large suitcase is limited. The bathroom is also tiny, especially the little but deep bath tub is not very comfortable, and there is limited space for private toiletries. No face towels. The breakfast buffet is very rich, offering both Asian and Western dishes, and all foods I had tried were tasty. Dinner is excellent (ate Japanese food) but the choice of menus is limited, and it is really expensive.

We visited this Hotel at the start of a tour and we knew nothing of Japanese hotels.By and large they were all similar in this chain.Firstly, it is apparently normal not to have storage facilities for clothes etc... and we found this limiting.Secondly, this hotel room was quite small but functional. The bathroom was adequate and furnished with a variety of toiletries which is again typical of Japanese hotels.Food wise, we were on a bed and breakfast tariff and the breakfast was excellent with an array of both Japanese and European breakfast foods........something for everybody's taste.Overall, apart from the size of the room, this hotel was both spotless and highly functional for the traveller.

Room was large by Tokyo standard so pleasantly surprised. Had two large single beds and still had room to open up rigid cases. Right opposite subway station and on busy road but the screens very effective in shutting out noise. Area has no shopping but lots of small eateries. Few stops to Ginza and major shopping areas. Caught hotel limousine bus from Haneda airport and being last stop on route took almost an hour. Buses to Haneda airport are irregular but I believe Narita route is much more frequent. Return journey only took half an hour. Allowed us to check in before 1pm though normal time is 2pm. Had their dinner buffet with Hokkaido theme and the crab claws were fabulous.

Have visited this hotel again and experienced their hospitality again. The best part of this hotel is the location. Restaurants, Metro, Banks, Convenience Stores, are all near by. The airport coach has drop and pick up facility which makes it convenient to reach and depart.

This is a fairly big hotel in a great location. The staff are friendly and helpful.Our room was large, with enough room for two people to share comfortably and not have your luggage constantly getting in your way. The room was extremely clean and tidy. In the room there was a kettle with tea and coffee. Also provided was a Nespresso coffee machine with capsules for dark and light coffee (an extremely nice touch).There is a small fridge in the room which is stocked with some bottles of water and cans of beer. The water and beer are charged for should you take them from the fridge. However there is space in the fridge should you buy your own bottles of water or cans of beer to keep cool.The bathroom was extremely clean and tidy. Provided were a selection of amenities hygienically packaged. Toothbrush and toothpaste, hair brushes, face cloths, razors and shaving gel. At the sink was a dispenser with hand and face soap. In the shower / bath were three dispensers offering shampoo, conditioner and body wash.The toilet had a heated toilet seat and built in bidet.This hotel has a restaurant and cigar bar and lonunge. I can't speak highly enough about the house keeping team. They are excellent. We asked for an iron and ironing board to be sent to our room and it was delivered in less than five minutes. Also I needed some items sent to the laundry. They were collected first thing on Monday morning and were waiting in our room on our return after a long day of sightseeing. The three shirts had been washed and ironed perfectly. Each sealed in plastic. When opened it was like putting on a brand new shirt. Adjoined very conveniently to the hotel is a 7 Eleven store with all the usual offerings. There are also various restaurants and a Tully's coffee shop within a very short walk from the hotel entrance.As mentioned earlier this hotel is in a great location at Akasaka-mitsuke on the Tokyo metro system.
