There are two entrances for this station at either end of the hotel. Akasaka-mitsuke metro station has five different metro lines that you can connect to via different station entrances or station walk ways.Most of the metro stations in Tokyo are huge in size. At first they can appear intimidating and confusing. No need to worry if you are patient and take your time to read and follow the signs which are in Japanese and English. By the ticket machines there is usually located a staffed information booth were you can get a metro map and ticket advice.The staff on the metro are extremely polite and helpful and all of the metro and station staff we spoke to on our trip helped us to navigate our way around this amazing city.I would highly recommend this hotel. It was a pleasure to stay at.

This hotel has all a business hotel needs. Rooms are reasonable, breakfast is OK. It is in walking distance to some nice restaurants and pubs.It has a direct bus connection to Narita airport and is therefore easy to reach

It was my first trip to Asia and my first stop was Tokyo. The room was tiny. No desk chair so it was difficult to work in the room. The bed was comfortable and the room was clean. I'm pretty tall and nearly hit the ceiling in the shower. Nice looking cation with lots of restaurants close but.

Great location, Smooth and efficient check-in/out. Ask for room 735 as it is quiet and quite large with a large bathroom relative to the room. All the amenities you will ever need and the toilet seat is worth the visit!!!! Staff polite (what do you expect in Japan) and efficient and helpful. BBC is in English if you follow instructions and press the right button on the remote control. Restaurants in-house are expensive but just behind the BIC Camera store (across the road) has a huge variety of eateries from every continent/city. There is also a Money Exchange booth which offers quite a good deal better rates than back in Oz so give it a try. The Limousine Bus drops off and picks up from this hotel so no worries transferring to/from Narita/Haneda airports. The BIC Camera store is a bit pricey but the alcohol store on level 5F is great stocks everything your little heart desires. Don't waste money on duty free grog at the airport.The JR and Tokyo Metro are just across the road or around the corner and easy to use.Behind the BIC camera store there are a plethora of eateries, bars, karoke bars, dens of inequity(dodgy bars) plus much more and much cheaper than eating at the hotel.A 7/11 store is located on the ground floor of the hotel and is open 24hrs a day for emergency supplies or a quick snack or a drop of wine!!!!. No safe deposit box in the room but the hotel has its own at check in.A great hotel worthy of a visit given its location, price and value for money. Will stay there when next we visit Tokyo

Great business hotel. Good location, next to subway, direct bus access to airports. Ask for a room looking at the garden it's less noisy and you can open the window. The room size is OK for Japan, no problem with cleaniness.

I've been in this oterl about 5 times for business purposes. Good value for money. Next to metro station. Direct stop for Limo Service bus transportation from Narita Airport..Very clean, good service. A bit too small the rooms. Plenty of elevators. Very well served breakfast area (and variety of food). Being close to Akasaka walkway, there is an incredible amount of choice about restaurants and entertainments. There is not a fintess room but right outisde there is an ANA sports center with an affordable dailiy fee. I use it regularly as it's open 6 am. In front of it a well served shopping center and plenty of nice places for bar, lounges. A convenient place to be and an insureance to be treated well. i would return and recommend.https://www.tripadvisor.it/ShowUserReviews-g1066443-d3676666-r391322024-Hotel_New_Otani_Tokyo_Garden_Tower-Chiyoda_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.html#

Stayed there for 2 weeks for business, the building and the rooms is a bit old but clean. Compare to the other local hotel in Toyko the room is with a right size at least I can lay my luggage open. And with a coffee table and working bench. There is a Nespresso machine and offer 4 capsules a day. Offer 1 bottle of water but need to put a voucher on the mini-bar check, not sure if everyone can get. Breakfast is so so with the choice of set or buffet, the buffet offer the same foods for my 2 weeks stay. The Akasaka area is quite quiet during the weekend and there is a nice Japanese temple near by and a nice park as well. There are two subway station near by so it is convenience.

This hotel has a great location with 5 metro lines across the road from the hotel. In addition, there is a Citibank ATM, convenience store, Starbucks and Tokyo metro pass vendor within walking distance from the hotel. It is important that you specify at the time of booking if you want a non-smoking room to avoid finding yourself in a smoking room accidentally. I stayed at this hotel twice during my trip (April 2015), at the start and at the end. At the start my room was on a floor that clearly been refurbished and was spacious and modern. At the end my room was on a floor that had yet to be refurbished and the room was spacious and comfortable if a bit dated. There was free wifi. Would definitely stay here again!

Stayed for 5 days (Cosmos Tour starts here) its good location for trains.Short walking distance to Otani Hotel for "hop-on hop-off pick up. RestaurantS across the street and "its cheap". Taxi from Tokyo train station only cost 1,500 Yen (very cheap to divide between 2 coupisles) and most important thing....its a "limousine bus" pick-up and drop off from Haneda Airport. Food is very Good but not on your 4th, or 5th day...same menu. EVERYONE very helpful. 7Eleven on the ground floor and BIC Camera is just infront of the building. The only thing is they dont have a swimming pool...only GYM.

This is a very central hotel with good connections to the metro and lots of restaurants nearby. There is a 7-11 store attached to the hotel which is very handy for getting drinks and snacks. The hotel also gives a free bottle of water daily in the room.

I really wanted to like this hotel, but it didn't really want to like me. It's central, close to transport (subway station and buses almost at the door), great restaurants and shopping close by and in spite of being flanked by an expressway and a main road, pretty quiet, although our room was at the back of the building. It is a big hotel, but the rooms are tiny. I know it's Tokyo but for two tall Australians with luggage etc it was an uncomfortably close and tight fit. Nowhere to put suitcases and no wardrobe - other than a small wooden partition about a metre long and 15cm away from one wall, which couldn't even accommodate the hangers provided, let alone any clothes. Comfortable beds though, and adequate bathroom. The breakfast buffet restaurant was OK but somewhat haphazardly arranged - the coffee machine as far away from the tables as you could get and no logic to the arrangement of the various (albeit plentiful) foods on offer. Doubles as the buffet restaurant for dinner. A nice but expensive bar on the 14th floor with a good view of the city if you can snag a table near the window. The staff were helpful in a slightly diffident way, but I'm not sure I'd go back again.

Just opposite of the subway, two key metro lines Ginza & Marunouchi lines.Hotel lobby located at 3/F, so it is quiet. Shops and restaurants on ground floor and 2/F.Service is good, can communicate in English as this is a business hotel.Room (22sq.m.), with a relatively big washroom, still enough for two big luggage.Will stay there again definitely.

Comfy room with loots of little extras like toothbrush, soaps, shavers Very clean and friendly staff. Breakfast was very nice but sometimes there is a long queue. It's situated in a building with a bar on the top floor which makes for some great views. They also give you a map of the area which is really helpful.

This hotel was clean and well located near to the subway and a shopping area. The heated toilet seat, took a bit of getting used too.I had a Japanese breakfast, which was small compared to our normal breakfast, but a still filling and adequate.

We stayed at the beginning of our trip and then at the end. Our first room on the 8th floor was too cramped, not enough space to hang our clothes or put them away. The room on the 9th floor was much better. Be careful when booking that you get a reasonable size room. It would appear that the higher the floor the better the rooms.The staff spoke good English and were very helpful. They serve a very good breakfast, both western and Japanese.The hotel is very central with lots of eateries nearby. The tube is right opposite.We will stay here again.

Very clean and good service , the room is smaller than average Hotel but comfortable . Centrally located and easy access to the underground station . Plenty of restaurants around the hotel . Very good breakfast and there is a convenient store to get your water etc. Will stay here again if I visit Tokyo.

This was the first hotel on our tour of Japan and we were very impressed with thus hotel. It is in a great location situated within easy walking distance of shops restaurant etc. Hotel is clean, room big enough for 1,2 or 3 nights - note not all rooms have a wardrobe, which we found strange, they have hooks behind the mirror! Another strange experience was the toilet seats - they are heated which is a bit of a shock at first. There was a goid selection of food at Breakfast accommodating all nationalities - very good. Hotel staff and service very good even if one feels uncomfortable about their tiny ladies doing all the heavy lifting of the cases. When my husband offered to help it was a definate no no. Happy hour was well used champagne at £3:50 a glass. Would recommend to all ages.

Like most hotels in Japan, it appears that many are conveniently located near a railway station and this one is no different. Close to the Akasaka-Mitsuke Tokyo Metro station.Arrival at the hotel is a pleasant experience and the check in process quite fluid. The elevators are quite good in that there is always one not far away.The room, WOW! I had a Standard Double and was totally impressed with it. Like any big city in the world, rooms are going to be somewhat smaller than what is expected. The Akasaka Excel have made the most of the small space and maximised it. The bed was comfortable and I found a way to "live" comfortably whilst travelling with two suitcases. I was fortunate to have a room on the off-street side which also seems to have been upgraded with a Nespresso machine (sadly lost on me as I'm not a coffee drinker). The bathroom was quite good, with a step up from the room to the basin wash area and then another step up to toilet and shower. The toilet seat was heated.Now the shower, I am missing it already it was that good. Wonderful overhead pressure and also jet sprays at back height which was impressive after lugging around a heavy camera all day.Absolutely no hesitation in recommending this hotel to you.

The hotel is just opposite of train station, which only 25 minutes to Haneda airport. There is a BIG Camera above the train station. And behind it, you can find plenty foods on the alleys which look like in Shinjuku. The hotel is an big old one but well maintained and the service is good.

It's not surprising , the service at most of the hotels in Japan at thisLevel is above average. Most of the hotel staff are very very polite , the food at breakfast is divers but if you are not Familiar with Japanese food you might find it very difficulties . The location of the hotel is very closed to a bars, restaurants , malls and underground station just near by.

Very well located hotel. Small but very comfortable hotel room, I am 6'2 and 260lb and had no issue with the room size, it is very compact by American standards but has everything you need on a business trip to Tokyo. The room is clean and the bathrooms are immaculate.Staff were friendly and understanding my English was not. A problem.Access to public transport is easy and the hotel provide a shuttle bus at minimal cost to the airports.I would recommend this hotel for anyone needing a place in this part of town.

The hotel is easily accessible by bus from the Narita airport and it is the last stop of the bus but it takes 1 1/2 to 2 hours of travel, although a comfortable clean bus. It is located on a busy street near shops, restaurants and the subway station is right across the street, therefore even with the windows closed and earplugs, one can hear some traffic. However the insulation between rooms is good, as one does not hear the other guests (such as TV or loud talking). The room is small for North American standards but acceptable and comparable to most European hotel rooms. The breakfast is sumptuous offering Japanese and Western fare and it is more of a lunch than even a brunch.There are sufficient elevators that one does not have to wait long for them. It is clean and the rooms offer a good bathroom, good firm beds, robes, a flat screen TV, although the choice of English language channels is extremely limited. The hotel restaurant serves dinner. We had one dinner there and it was good accompanied also by good service.

Check in/ check out is a breeze! Right across SHOPPING / FOOD areas! Nice place to jog around in the morning, very safe with a nearby POLICE station! Very convenient! Small rooms BUT well equipped! Comfortable beds with good amenities!

This is a nice hotel. My only complaint would be that the carpet in my room was a little too stained for my liking. I was initially placed in a very small room. I immediately went to the front desk and asked about moving to a larger room. This was granted for a nominal additional fee. The breakfast buffet is so so for a westerner ( I am sure lovely for locals). I don't have really any complaints just nothing great that I can place my finger on. If available, I would definitely stay up the street at the New Otani (The Main) as my experience there was much nicer.

We stayed at this hotel as part of our Cosmos tour package. The location was excellent, with the railway station opposite the hotel and the quaint older area of Tokyo only a stone's throw away. The area has many international restaurants including an excellent selection of Italian ones, all very reasonably priced. In fact, food in the restaurants was not nearly as expensive as we had been led to believe. Even fish and chips is available for those who are less adventurous! However, the hotel breakfast which was included in the price of package was disappointing. The Japanese breakfast offered a reasonable selection but the American/Western style breakfast was very limited. One could have scrambled or boiled eggs, bacon, small sausages and a small selection of bread rolls, most of which were on the sweet side. Moreover, the food was lukewarm or cold, making it less than appetising. The coffee was quite good. There can be a long queue so it is a good idea to go to breakfast early. In addition, the bedrooms were not very comfortable. The first room that was offered to us, a double one, was so small that there was nowhere to place our two suitcases and hanging space was almost non-existent. We asked the hotel reception to transfer us to a room with more space and we were were given a room with twin beds, overlooking the main street. The staff were very obliging in allowing us to change rooms. Reasonable English was spoken at reception. Another point is that the mattresses are extremely firm, which one can get used to. However, the two pillows on my bed were difficult to sleep on! One pillow had husks, rather like small marbles inside and the other was filled with some sort of sandlike substance - I believe it was buckwheat. Both were extremely uncomfortable to sleep on. I asked for a softer pillow on our second day and the staff obliged,mercifully! There is a small smoking room in the foyer area but it does not have chairs.

I actually stayed here on the last week of Feb 2014. The place was very comfortable. I enjoyed every single day of my stay. The breakfast selection is fine but can still be further improved. I also like the fact that it is near 7-eleven stores and subway station. I miss this place.

Great location with train station right across the road (below the BIC electronics shop), 7 eleven downstairs and plenty of restaurants to eat around. Room was ok size and very clean. All staff friendly and helpful. Little challenge with my washing shrinking - but minor issue for what was a great stay.

This hotel has created huge problems for me by double charging me for a room. Despite having asked them 3 times while I was at the hotel and tree times by email after leaving the hotel, they still haven't refunded the 30,000 yen that they took from by debit card. They said they refunded it after my first request, then when asked again, said sorry we forgot, the next request was the same, yes we refunded but then no it was an oversight, we forgot again - and more then two weeks later they still have not refunded the unauthorized transaction.

The hotel is in an ideal location, you can walk or get the train to everywhere in Tokyo. The room size was good, the bed very comfortable, although make sure you ask for a non smoking room if the smell of smoke offends. Across the road is the restaurant and entertainment area - something new and different to eat and see every night.

Stayed at this hotel during our honeymoon to Japan. Just took a standard double room. Hotel Staff go above and beyond in the name of service- Nothing is too much trouble. Air conditioning, Air Humidifier, kimonos and smart toilet all included in the room. An Iron was provided on request. Extremely comfortable bed. Hotel is on a busy road however so be warned if you are a light sleeper. We had no such trouble.Strange design of bathroom in that there is a window that looks out into the room presumably so you can watch the TV while you are on the lovely heated toilet seat. There was a venetian blind so you could have privacy if you so desired.....I didn't.Fantastic restaurant on top floor of hotel, very classy but very expensive. Main hotel restaurant serves great buffet breakfast with lots of western foods in addition to traditional Japanese breakfasts but anything other than breakfast in this restaurant is not worth the money especially as there are so many good eats for much cheaper in the bustling district of Akasaka just over the road from the hotel.Akasake-Mitske Train station is also over the road and you can be right in the centre of Tokyo in minutes

The Hotel itself is very accesible, mulitple subway lines go through the nearby station Akaska mitsuke.The room we had was a bit small, but it served it's purpose. The restaurant was good, nothing spectacular, but quality food.We tried the breakfast once, it's wasn't cheap and wasn't for us.The area around the hotel has a lot to offer in the way of restaurants and some shopping. I can certainy recommend it as long as you don't spend to much time in your room and use the fact that you can easily go anywhere in Tokyo.

Stayed twice in a week in two different rooms. First single room was "compact". Twin room worked better.Close to Palace if you want a walk (5 kms around parameter) . Big C shop directly opposite. Interesting restaurants and bars nearby.Basic place to stay with reasonable breakfast buffet.

The service cannot be faulted, but the rooms smelled very strongly of cigarette smoke. The stench was so bad it made my nose and throat sore when sleeping. The room was minimalist in size, but adequate.

We stayed there for some 12 hrs on the way from Hawaii. It is well connected by subway so we could get there easily from Haneda and use the few hours we had to see a few things in Tokyo. It is probably a bit too basic for a longer stay but for our transit it was just right. We were told we'd have connected rooms but they didn't have them when we arrived. I am not sure they don't have them at all or if something went wrong with the booking. That was fine for the one night we had but for longer inconvenient.

At the Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu you experience the real Japanese service. Every member of the hotel team is there for you as a customer. It's something you feel in the small things like the friendly greetings, the bell boy who quickly goes to the elevator and holds it when you arrive so you don't have to wait, the reception desk quickly providing extra staffing so no queues rise at check out time.We found our 1 night stay very good.Let's go for a systematic overview.LOCATION: very easy - about 10min taxi from Tokyo station, or take the subway to Akasake-mitsuke station (just 2 stops from Tokyo station).SURROUNDING AREA: the hotel has a shopping gallery next to it. At ground floor level you have a 7Eleven supermarket where you can find anything from medication to bread to yoghurt and some wine...allowing for a cheap breakfast if you want. Across the street (where also the subway station is) you have a very big BIC electronics store. The BIC store sells all electronics and cameras on 7 floors...and a tip, there's a very nice liquor store located on the 5th floor of BIC: great choice of beers, wines, whisky, champagne and of course Sake.RECEPTION: very friendly and professionalROOMS: rather small (normal for Tokyo), very clean, very good bed with an amazing choice of cushions (memory foam, pits, feathers,...you can even request additional types), very quiet airconditioning, small bathroom with bath and shower located in the edge of the room. There's also a fridge, a water cooker with different temperature settings so you can prepare tea, a Nespresso machine with 4 capsules, TV, free Wifi, and sufficient storage space for luggage (see also pictures).Be aware that street noise is present in the rooms facing the street.A recommended hotel and I wouldn't hesitate to go back there - although not cheap, it fits within the hotel prices in Tokyo.

The hotel is easy to find from akasaka mitsuke station - Ginza line, and easy transfer to JR line from Tokyo Sta. the room is moderate spacious with equipment, at the 1st floor you can find a seven eleven store and the hotel near tokyu store, bic camera store just cross from hotel n hotel easy access to airport with limousine bus vv.

A typical Japanese business hotel with modern, clean, but small rooms. My room had every comfort but I had some problems putting all my clothes after unpacking my suitcase. Well, for 3 nights I could manage.The staff is very friendly, as usual in Japan. Check-in was quick and efficient. I did not use any restaurants in the hotel, so I can't judge about these.Many restaurants and shops around the hotel, so there is no problem to pass your time in the evening.The prices are - like always in Japan - not cheap, but acceptable.Very recommendable, I would always stay here again when in this region.

Been stayed here 3 times during my business trip. Best thing is the location. The station (Akasaka Mitsuke) is just across the hotel. It's interchange station, you can go to ginza or shibuya without changing line. There are many restaurants near to the station, takoyaki shop, electronic store: bic camera, even 24 shop: don quijote.As for the hotel itself, room is quite big for japan size, the amenities are extremely complete. I thinks Japanese is very thoughtful when it comes to hotel amenities. Breakfast is good, enough varieties.

The rooms are big enough for 3 of us with an extra bed set up. There is a 7-11 on the 1st floor of the hotel and the hotel is linked to a shopping centre. There is a electronic store opposite the hotel too. Although its snowing outside but i don't know why the room is so hot.. We have to request for a fan for our stay for 3 days. Lucky they have a fan for us...

Nice hotel , room are big to Japan in the area you have nice place for food and electronic shop .10 min by taxi from Sinjuko area and also you have train station near the hotel Breakfast is nice but not greatPrice is ok for Tokyo If you want bars you can find but to enjoy you need to go Sinjuko

Convenient hotel. Beds not the best however I love this part of Tokyo. The surrounding area is great to explore and its with easy walking distance of several sifferent Tokyo Metro lines so its open access to Tokyo from here.

As many other people have already expressed, the rooms are not very spacious, but they contain everything you need. I had a room with a queen size bed (I think) which was quite comfortable. The bathroom was clean and very functional. One of the best things about is the nice location being sort of in the middle of Tokyo. You can easily get to Shibuya station and from there go to all the interesting spots (Shinjuku, Harajuku), but you can also get to all the places in the south east of Tokyo like Ginza, Odaiba. Also, compared to a place in Shibuya (which seems to be more popular), the Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu is slightly closer to places in the north east like Asakusa and saves you some time in the metro.

The hotel has direct bus service from haneda and narita airports in Tokyo. Also cross the street to take the Tokyo Metro on Akasaka-Mitsune station to get around the city. There is good shopping across the street as well. A bottle of Choya which is sold for 1200 yen in the airport is only 1101 after taxes here. The hotel is comfortable and there is also a 711 downstairs in B1 which is open all the time if uou need anything.

Stayed at the Akasaka Excel for 7 nights while in Tokyo for a conference and a visit to some friends. Our deluxe twin room was comfortable and quite spacious for a Japanese hotel. The room aircon didn't seem to work and for the first few nights we kept the window open, but it was very noisy. There was a stand alone portable aircon unit but it didn't have instructions in English. We eventually got it to work and then enjoyed some better night's sleep. The hotel staff were extremely polite, helpful and efficient. The bar on the 14th floor is a must at happy hour every evening. Breakfast was fine with a mixture of Japanese and western food. The hotel is opposite a subway station which gives easy access to all parts of Tokyo. All-in-all a very good base from which to explore this really interesting city, we would stay there again.

Well located in Chibuya, next to shops and restaurants, this hotel offers high quality service. The closest subway stop is just on the opposite side of the street.Rooms are small, but not smaller than in equivalent or even more expensive hotels, and the available space is optimised. Everything is perfectly clean and the bathroom remains comfortable despite its size.You can use 2 complimentary bottles of water from the minibar daily. Wifi in the rooms is free and good enough to have a clean conversation on Skype or watch a film on Netflix. I haven't seen a safe in the room though.Breakfast is good with a lot of choice. Not the most impressive I have seen, but I must admit I did not use much of its Japanese part so if you like Japanese food at breakfast you will have even more choice.If you want to have dinner, there is a quite interesting buffet at the 3rd floor at a very reasonable price. If you are looking for something more classy, go to the 14th floor where you will also find a nice bar.If you can, ask for a room on the backyard. These room are very quiet and the view on the garden is really nice.

We were upgraded to a larger room on a lady's only floor, which had an extra security door and complimentary toiletry gift pack. The room is very new and pleasant, with playful touches, and of course super clean. The hotel is located across the station and the airport shuttle bus departs from the front entrance, so it is extremely convenient. However, reception is on the 3rd floor and there is a upscale shopping centre and restaurants on the ground floor, 1st and 2nd floor, plus underground parking. The lifts do not require swipe cards to operate and is essentially open to the public, so security is a bit lax. Though Japan is very safe and the area is a business district, so we won't concerned.

I booked a set of rooms at the Akasaka Excel, a hotel I like and have stayed at several times before, and would stay again. It is a good hotel, good location near the metro. My issue with my most recent stay is with the arrangements between the hotel and Agoda - Agoda did not offer non-smoking rooms like they do with other properties and despite booking four months in advance, on arrival was given three very smoky rooms. As the hotel was full, it was basically a take it or leave it situation - not very good. The two companies (Tokyu and Agoda) need to sort this out.Otherwise, a good stay, and helpful staff. Special mention goes to the organisation for medical assistance (my wife needed to consult a doctor) with clear instructions for accessing a nearby clinic with English speaking staff. Having traveled often enough to need this service from hotels several times before, this was the best we have encountered.

Good location just opposite Akasaka Mitsuke station and a large Bikku Camera store. I arrived at 10:30am which was obviously too early to get into my room, however the staff were very efficient at processing my check in and taking my bags. When I returned later in the day I simply had to pick up my key card and my bags were waiting for me in my room. It was a great service.A number of reviews commented on the small rooms, however I actually found my single room to be more spacious than other single rooms I've stayed at in Japan. As per other reviews, the shower was great! The other in room facilities, including free and fast wifi, were also perfect which made for a pleasant stay. I was at the back of the hotel which overlooks some government residences with nice gardens, so it felt like a little green oasis in the middle of Tokyo.All in all a very pleasant stay.

Great accessibility from both the Narita and Haneda airport. The airport limousine goes directly to this hotel. There were a number of restaurants just opposite the hotel. The Metro station is also located just opposite the Hotel. Very convenient to get around.

This hotel is about an hour from Narita airport ( costs about 3000 yen per person in airport limo bus) it is fairly central as you can access other parts of Tokyo fairly easily from it, and there are plenty of restaurants and bars in the area across the street .You enter at ground level and take a lift to reception. Check in was easy . The hotel is fairly old,rooms are small- they have a mini bar with beer and water ( don't really need this as there is a Lawsons convenience store at entrance on ground level) ,tea and kettle,A/C, TV ( only BBC news in English) free wifi ( you need a code) but there is no safe.Our room ( keycard entry) had 2 single beds which were very firm and very low. Our window looked out on the front and had paper shutter/ screens as well as blackout curtains.The bathroom was a 'pod' ( very compact!) and had a bath with shower over it , hairdryer and a basket of toiletries and plenty towels . The toilet was a Toto washlet - heated seat,bidet spray ,deodoriser etc - first time I had seen this and I was quite amused!Breakfast was a buffet- plenty Japanese style food , some English breakfast foods choice of 3 cereals and a small amount of fresh fruit , breads to toast but no cheese at all.There is a bar on the top floor which was a bit dingy as smoking was allowed in it and it was expensive £11 per pint - so don't waste your money - there are plenty bars in the district across the street !Adequate and clean this hotel does the job!

meet my 2 criteria : easy access from airport - limousine bus stop right at the hotel ; free wifi - strong signal in the room. Metro Akasaka-mitsuke opposite the hotel so you can move around in the city. Staff are friendly and this is no surprise all over Japan. Our room (1010) is reasonably spacious by Japan standard. Kettle available so you can make a cup of tea but no coffee pack provided. You can pick one from 7-eleven downstairs for 300 yen. Plenty of restaurants around. Akasaka-mitsuke station is on the same line for Kokki-gijidamae (Japan parliament), Ginza station (shopping) and Tokyo (Imperial Palace), Shinjuku (shopping) etc. Definitely will stay again

Was in Tokyo for work and we stayed at Akasaka Excel Tokyu for its central location and accessibility by both the airport limousine bus and metro lines. Hotel: 1. Need refurbishment but adequate with kettle for hot water and hot drinks. But Room on 10th floor does not provide coffee which will be much appreciated2. Not very sound proof3. Good breakfast (Japanese) and you can buy the bfast voucher at JPY2,500. Currently, there is a promotion at JPY2,200Nearby area:1. Bic Camera (6 floors of shopping which include cosmetics and pharma (small section), electronics, homeware and liquor section. The liquor section has Suntory's Yamazaki which is currently very popular and where there is no stock at the duty free shops at Narita airport2. Convenience store 7-11 on ground floor of hotel, very convenience for snacks and toiletries. Prices of face masks like Lululun and Kose sunblock are same as in Don Quiyote3. Hooters restaurant and Ninja restaurants nearby4. Behind Bic Camera (which is opposite the Hotel) are two streets filled with restaurants and some pharma shops including one Can Do (alternative to 100yen) shop.Good value for money especially if you can sign up as Tokyu members (there is a 10% disc for members). But remember to sign up first and inform them clearly at the check in counter.

Stayed here at the beginning of our stay and at the end of our stay. Great location opposite a metro station and on the route for the airport buses.The rooms were small but normal for Japan. Clean with good facilities. We had a room at the back which was very quiet. As a business hotel it is efficient but also relaxed and friendly. The staff were friendly and helpful.

Revisited this hotel after about 12 years, and hasn't changed much - just looks a lot older now. Rooms are very small and no wardrobe as such and no room to put luggage (or anything else). At least they have one English TV channel now...and a 7-Eleven on the ground floor. The Hooters branch was also a new addition for me.Service very good, but have had better in Tokyo to be honest. Limousine bus for Narita stops right outside, so easy to get to and from the Airport. Haneda is a bit more difficult and resorted to taxi in the end.Didn't eat in and just used the place for sleeping - couldn't do much else in the room really. Just beware the quilt cover as it appears to be made of some man-made non-porous fibre that caused me a sweaty night or two until I realised, and then slept with it off!On the positive side the shower is one of the best I have ever had in a hotel and was fantastic to wake up to. No bath obviously as too small to fit one. Would think twice about staying again, but the location for restaurants and Metro network is hard to beat.

The rooms are very small and lack drawer space and space to put the smallest of luggage. (We came with just 2 carry ons & 2 back packs). The rooms have no safes. The location is very good near underground stations, restaurants and clubs. The breakfast buffet is quite nice. It's a decent hotel.

Small rooms but very well equipped and functional. Having several restaurants within a short walk was the real bonus. Easy access to public transport and taxis always available outside the door. 711 grocery store on site.
user_name:
Richard190
Royal Tunbridge Wells, United Kingdom

review_body: Nice hotel at good price level, nice rooms and location is quite good. 10 minutes to Roppongi and shuttle bus takes from front of the hotel to Narita airport in 1,5 hours.I didn't have any food or drinks at this hotel.

Ideally suited to explore the city , rooms are clean and modern, free wifi , flat screen TV , tea and coffee making on hand . My first stay in a Japanese hotel so the toilet was a novelty with heated seat and multi function ! .Surrounded by restaurants and shops and bars.

The hotel is very popular due to its convenient location. It is across the street for the Akasaka-Mitsuke station on the marunouchi line and ginza line.It is 3 stops from Omotesando station, 4 stops from ginza station, 4 stops from Shinjuku and 4 stops from Tokyo station.On top of the station is a 9sty shop called Bic Camera. It is a must see destination, other than cameras, they have a drug store in B1 as you exit the station, a liquor shop on the 5th floor and a stationery shop on the 4th floor. Prices are cheaper than most retailers.The akasaka area on the other side of the station is a few streets choked full of restaurants and drinking holes. There is even a decent supermarket.So the hotel is well positioned for both business and shopping. The 7-11 within the same complex is also well stocked if you will not walk 5 minutes to Akasaka for the usual lawson and family mart.The breakfast buffet offers a good selection of western and japanese style spread with very fresh ingredients. Very dependable for 2500Yen if it is not included in the room price.The rooms are small, typical in Tokyo but generally larger than those around Shinjuke stations and the APA chains.The hotel was closed for renovation and reopened a few years ago. The bathroom with a decent size tub (by that i mean you need to be not more than 165cm tall) is still spotless. But the carpet inside the room was already showing signs of wear and tear and stains. This is my only gripe.Otherwise all good.Oh, and the cherry on top of the icing for me would be the limousine bus service to both Narita and Haneda Airports that departs from the hotel. So wonderful to have after a long work week and extra suitcase from all that shopping.

The hotel is well located with a wide number of shops and bars in the area, this is welcome news s the hotel itself has no bar.Bedrooms are very small with limited space - no irons in the room for the business traveller I would say this was ok but not wow.

Perfect location of a very nice hotel. The hotel is in near hundreds of restaurants and bars. The food for breakfast and dinner was excellent. The rooms are newly decorated. Rooms are small but comfortable with all necessary things, including nespresso machine, tea, minibar, comfortable bed, air conditioned, etc. The service was excellent.

I've been at this hotel for twice. Locatio is very good. Subway and Bic Camera in front of him. Good restaurants around. Breakfast is good. Wifi is regular but rooms are very very smalls. If you will stay up to 1 week, it's OK. More than this period, you will need more space....

Third floor lobby. Friendly staff. Efficient hotel room. Water well warmed and pressure. Close to trains that led to popular tourist and dining spots. Organised breakfast buffet. Enjoyed the Japanese choices besides continental ones. Tables reserved with a coaster marker to one's convenience and confidence while getting food. Helpful staff had maps and guided me to my destinations. Quiet at night. Night lamp helpful between my roommate and myself with jetlag also between us. Near shopping mall. Go for it!

✅ location works opposite the subway station✅ hotel checkin is fast ✅ no pool✅ no gym ✅ feels like a hospital ✅ rooms are extremely small ✅ old and dated rooms✅ wifi is patchy ✅ bathroom is extremely small ✅ smelled a little ✅ expensive hotel for the quality of hotel ✅ room rate is probably based on location Would not stay again not worth it

Very nice hotel, in a really great location. Right across the Ginza line train, and lots of great shops and restaurants. Not a lot of frills though (no pool for example), but it serves its purpose. Staff was friendly, accommodating and speaks English very well.

+ The position is very good just in front of a metro station and surrounded by shops and restaurant. We had a dinner in the Hotel restaurant and it was good, but as mentioned there are many options around. - Room facing the main road are not soundproofed. Without plugs I wouldn't have close an eye.

I really like this hotel. The location is great and the mid-century feel of this hotel is wonderful. They also have a great restaurant and they serve an impressive breakfast. The hotel is close to train stations and surrounded by a ton of shopping. If you are looking for an upscale, new and really fancy hotel, then skip this one. If you are looking for an affordable, clean and impressive hotel, this is a really good choice. While I was there, I saw tourists and business people staying at this hotel. It's a nice mix of patrons.

Very pleased with the central location, staff helpfulness and overall facilities. Not sparkling new but very clean, relatively quiet and close to the Metro and some amazing restaurants. The only drawback is lack of fitness center but there is a full service gym 1 block away for about $17 usd per day. Also I recommend the transfer from Narita to here directly using the Limousine Bus service which departs every hour from Narita and will deposit you and your luggage at the hotels door for $25. No transfers at all.

The Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu is a good central location, immediately opposite Akasaka-mitsuke metro station.My room was a reasonable size for Tokyo with everything you need – nice comfy bed, average-sized bathroom, desk space to work. Very good breakfast with lots of choice. Nice, always attentive staff.As an aside, try out the Yona Yona Beer Kitchen Akasaka 30 seconds away in the same block for great food and great beer; you might want to book as it gets very busy.

We found this hotel to be very convenient for touring in Tokyo. Subway stop nearby.The room was very comfortable and reasonably spacious (by Japanese standards) The breakfast buffet had a good assortment of eastern and western food.The hotel is near a number of good restaurants and they provided us with a map showing the location of the restaurants. We ate in the hotel dining room our last night since it was pouring rain at the time. The food was outstanding but a bit on the expensive side..The staff was helpful and accommodating. We were able to store our luggage at the desk on our last day, as our flight did not leave until evening. We are able to walk to the Imperial Palace garden for a pleasant day before catching the shuttle from the hotel to the airport in the late afternoon.

Came to Tokyo again for the shopping season and a bit of sightseeing rural area. Decided to come back to Excel due to its great location, right in between Tokyo JR and Shinjuku station (which leads to rural places like Nikko).My room this time is a bit bigger. The facilities are just as good as before and service is excellent as always.The beanbag like pillow is so good I decided to buy a similar one from Bic Camera.Just 2 further improvements that the hotel can make. 1) the shower is wayyyyy too stuffy and steamy when the rainbath showerhead is turned on for awhile. can barely breathe after 10 to 15 min. it appears there is no ventilation fan in the shower. why? 2) pleaseeee get better toilet papers like 2-ply or 3-ply. the ones they have now is way too thin for proper cleaning.aside from these, I love this hotel very much. opposite of Bic Camera, drugstore and Choco Croc (I love that place, a cafe with heavenly chocolate croissant), with a convenient store beside it. there is also shuttle service directly to airport.next time I come to Tokyo, I will definitely stay here again.

Having read reports of noisy rooms, I asked for a quiet room and was delighted by a room at the back of wine hotel overlooking a park of tall trees; beautiful. Being on my own, I had plenty of room and enjoyed the tea/ coffee making facilities, the deep bath, free wifi and sumptuous breakfast. The service was excellent helping me with Internet, booking my shuttle, carrying bags and advising on local restaurants of which there are many. I'll be back.

Many people think of Shinjuku or Shibuya as good Tokyo hotel destinations, but we have stayed in the Akasaka area several times (including at the Prince which is now a huge building site). The hotel is most easily accessed from the Akasaka-mitsuke station as it is directly across the road (on both the Ginza and Maranouchi subway lines), but the Nagatacho station is also very close. This makes it a good location for exploring the city, but does require a transfer when travelling to/from Tokyo.For a hotel with almost 500 rooms, check-in on the 3rd floor was pretty quick and the space was a useful meeting point for our group. The rooms (we had booked superior doubles) were comfortable and enough space to relax for the several days we were in Tokyo.Other nice things were the 7-11 and the Tullys Coffee shop on the ground floor - made breakfast and getting snacks very easy.

We stayed at the Akaska Excel Hotel Tokyu over a year ago and enjoyed the stay. We came back again and had a very different experience. We got a slightly smaller room (due to my error in reading the room sizes) and could not upgrade. What had previously been an altogether pleasant experience dropped back to average. Our room was small, crowded and uncomfortable. It made for a very long week with two of us in the room. This time around, the service was not up to the previous standard either. Not a terrible experience, but a bit disappointing overall.

This hotel as perfect for our stay,7 nights two teenager boys over 6ft. The room was small but it had a deep bath and the boys loved that. It was across the road from the station and in fact it was close to all lines so it made everything easy. also there is lots of noodle restaurants in a ally way across from this hotel behind the Camera shop.We bought breakfast on the street or at 7 Eleven as the breakfast is expensive 75.00 Aus for 3 of us in the hotel. The hotel staff are knowledgeable and friendly.beds are comfy, but I have to say Im a fussy pillow sleeper and there pillows didn't work for me at all. They are hard like rocks.We were out most days from 8am till 10pm so it really was just a place to sleep for us that was central to everything.

Big sprawling hotel, with restaurants and shops on lower level, reached by lift or escalator.....Main public area's on the whole in good order, however in need of some refurbishment, i.e. painting and decorating. Bedrooms a good size, all expected amenities including hairdryer, tea/coffee (although it was green tea) free WIFI, plenty of hot water and a lovely small deep bath. Modern heated , (all singing all dancing) toilet, which is normal in most western hotels.Our room 819 could do with new fixtures and carpets. ....dirty and stained....However on the whole met our needs. We had excellent views with minimal disruption from the noise of police sirens etc. during the night. The dining room was run efficiently, good variety and choices for buffet breakfast, with lovely efficient pleasant staff on hand if there was any problem. Checking in and out was efficient and prompt.

It turned to be a very convenient hotel to stay, even though not at the very center of the city.Conveniently located opposite to Metro station (and an electronics shop if you wish). The area is full of restaurants, or every type and price range. Numerous shopping opportunities as well.The fact that there is a bus stop from/to the airports right in front of the hotel can be proved very convenient (provided that the time table suites your schedule). You may buy tickets to the airport from the hotel which is also helpful.The staff was very friendly and eager to meet our requirements.The breakfast covered a wide variety of tastes, without exaggerated offerings.The venue was not excessively luxurious and, in some cases, the need for better maintenance or renovation was apparent.Upon your arrival, go directly to the 3rd floor, where the reception is located.The single rooms may be quite small, so make sure that you book a room type appropriate to your needs. Working in the room desk may also proved to be a challenge, as far as the space concerns.Expect to find some coffee making equipment, mini-bar, yukata, sleepers and a variety of other amenities.Free WiFi was accessible in all areas, with average speed, but with some occasional interruptions.If you are a smoker, you may ask for a smoking room. Otherwise, your next alternative will be the smoking room close to the breakfast area, open from 6am to 11pm (I think). You are in Japan, so forget about smoking on the street.It is certainly not the most luxurious stay I ever had in Tokyo, but it was satisfying for the price range that was offering.Enjoy.

We traveled to Japan to visit our son stationed there and we brought his girlfriend along. So the three of us shared a room for a couple of nights until we got to base, interesting travel... This is a nice, clean, centrally located hotel with a good restaurant and bar. The room was tight, with three single beds and one bathroom, but we managed, after all we were in Tokyo!! The restaurant was very good, we only ate breakfast there but it was excellent. You can get American or Japanese style -- we went with a mix of both, chopsticks and all. It was fun and delicious. The hotel is reasonably priced, breakfast not included. Most of the staff spoke at least some English and were very polite and helpful. We had enough towels, but the bathroom was tiny. The people are extremely friendly and mostly American friendly. We went out both nights for dinner and to walk around and see the sights. There is a bustling area right across the street that has pretty much all kinds of yummy Asian food. It's a cab ride to the Imperial Palace and minutes from a gorgeous shrine within walking distance. It was our first time to Japan and but for the awful jet lag upon returning I loved everything about it. I would recommend this hotel.

We stayed here for 5 nights and it was a very good choice. It is located opposite the Akasake-Mitsuke subway and there is a row of shops and restaurants behind the Bic Camera Store there, so perfect for a nice meal or some quick grocery shopping after a long day of sightseeing. Check in was quick and bag storage was excellent and we were able to leave our bags and go and sight see straight away. The limousine bus was very handy from the aiport, a good thing to research before you go, a much cheaper option than a taxi or private transfer and easy to do too. We booked non smoking rooms and they were very good, nicely appointed and very comfortable and quiet. It was good that you could open the windows a little too. I would certainly recommend this hotel for a relaxing and comfortable stay in Tokyo with the ability to get the subway easily.

We stayed here for 4 nights in a double room facing the station. There were no non-smoking rooms available so we had a smoking room but you could open the window and we didn't suffer from a smell of smoke.The location is fantastic, across from Akasaka Station. Although the fittings in the room were a little worn, the room was spotlessly clean, the bed comfortable and the shower good. You stay here for the location and price - don't expect a luxury hotel - and we would definitely stay again.

We booked this hotel well in advance of our business trip to Tokyo requesting non-smoking rooms. When we got there we were given smoking rooms without any apology or excuse. The stay turned into a nightmare as the stench in the rooms was hard to bare. Walls are thin and so are the windows. Not a good place for anyone with trouble sleeping. There is wifi and the location is perfect for visiting most parts of Tokyo – but beware of the arrogant staff and make sure you get a non-smoking room.

The hotel was extremely well located which made getting around Tokyo easy. It's is walking distance to a large range of restraunts. The rooms are on the smaller side as you might expect but well appointed.

Stay 6 night in this hotel. Reasonable price if you book early and stay for more nights.The location is very good. The subway is just opposite the hotel separated by a road. It is also one of the hotel stop for airport limousine bus. Staff can speak good English and helpful. I booked a double room which is very spacious. There are even a Nespresso coffee machine with capsules provided in the room. Downside is they do not provide milk or milk powder. Few things to note:1. We heard quite a number of siren by the emergency vehicle at night. At approximately 11.20pm, there is always a siren followed by an announcement in Japanese which lasted a few seconds. Hotel may need to look into their sound proofing. We usually sleep late thus it never affect us much.2.Although the hotel claimed as a 4- star facility, their air conditioning system works like most of the 2 or 3-star hotel in Europe. The air-con will purge out hot air as long as the outside temperature fall into certain range. That does not matter whether your room is hot and humid. Most of the night I will just turn off the air-con and leave the window open.

Good lobby and location though the hotel rooms were a bit dated, but functional nevertheless. Overall I would feel there could be better value for money in the neighbourhood. The hotel staff was courteous and restaurant was decent for a snack.

We stayed 2 nights in the hotel whilst on a visit to Tokyo during the cherry blossom season. The underground station is just across the road from the hotel and there area has many restaurants. The rooms are small like most hotels in Japan. The bathroom is also small and comes with shower and a long bath. We did not eat in the hotel and so unable to comment on the quality of food. Service is good and the staff are helpful. Free wifi is available throughout.

The Akasaka Excel is a large hotel in the business district but close to the underground Akasaka-Mitsuke and Ginza and Marunouchi lines just across the road. Well located to access Tokyo attractions. There are also many cafes and restaurants in streets just across the road and in the area so good choices for dining in walking distance. The room we had, a deluxe double was quite spacious; the furnishings were somewhat tired and the decor was a mix of traditional and modern. Bed was comfortable and pillows provided were grain filled and regular. The bathroom was large with an effective spa style shower.The downside was that during the time we were there the cooling function of the air conditioning was not operating and the room became hot and stuffy as you cannot open windows. The provision of a fan made the room more comfortable.The staff service however was excellent and all staff that we came in contact with were friendly and efficient.So overall a recommendation for the hotel and location.

I was traveling with a business colleague and we booked two rooms non-smoking because she has asthma. They tried to put us in smoking rooms when we got there since they did not have any non-smoking rooms left. I put my foot down and they put us in slightly nicer rooms which is all they had available. I can't imagine staying in the original rooms which were tiny. Even our rooms had very little room, but it is Tokyo. The bathroom however was very nice. Excellent location. Good wifi.

This hotel is well located for the metro and is on the airport bus route. There are lots of places to eat round the hotel.But the room was dated and poorly designed. The large bed was too big for the space available resulting in poor access each side, particularly the side with the room light switches and telephone. There was very limited storage space for clothes. The room was hot and stuffy with no opening window and an air conditioning unit which could heat but not cool.The bathroom was good but had a shower, no bath.Breakfast was good.

Rooms are dated and the beds are of poor quality. We had the air conditioning set to high and no air came out. The windows are single panes only so you hear all the street noise. This is the worst hotel I have stayed at given how much they charge for it.

We stayed for three nights. The room was adequate for my husband and I as we were only there for a short time and only used it for sleeping and showering as we were out sightseeing all day. Lots of restaurants to choose from surrounding the hotel, especially McDonalds across the road. There was a station opposite and one to the left of the hotel which linked to Tokyo station.

Me and family (3 adults & 2 kids)Stayed here for 5nightsThe hotel room is quite small,Because i add 1 extra bed.So there is no more space left for us to move.The hotel is a bit old, but still very clean.The lobby is on the 3rd floorOn the 2nd floor got HootersOn the 1st floor got 7Eleven and couple of shop.The best of this hotel is located on the interchange of 5 subway station. Although it is all not JR Lines. But it is very helpfull.In front of the hotel, there is BIC Camera dept store. 8 floor store. Mostly sell electronics, but they also got sport equipment, toys, etc.And behind the BIC Camera there are so many restaurant, cafe. There are many kind if foods.We already tried Katsu, Ramen Shop, itamae sushi, and also Mcdonald

We stayed here one night whilst on a trip to Japan. The location is its strong point being across the road to a train station that links easily to all the major tourist spots in Tokyo and is only 4 stops from Tokyo station. This is helpful if you are using the train system to get to the airport and access to the bullet train system for further access to most of Japan. The other good point is that across the road and in the streets behind the station, there is a fantastic array of restaurants to tempt the taste buds. The place is a little tired for a big city hotel but the staff were pleasant enough. There were some significant bad points. Despite requesting a non smoking room, it took all day to get the smell of the smoke coming from the bathroom, presumably from the last occupant who didn't know/care of its non smoking status. The really annoying point was the air conditioning. It defaults to 22 degrees Celsius and then when you try and turn it down it won't allow less that 20. There was some weird round thing which I assume was a portable air conditioner but it's fan hardly put any air out. If you have heat loving daughters, no real issue but with 4 hot males the situation was pretty ridiculous as none of us sleep in a room heated to 20. The window, for safety reasons, only marginally opens which is understandable but didn't help our cause. I would happily stay in this area again but would perhaps look for another hotel unless you like it smoky hot!

I have stayed in this hotel three times, its awesome! It is a Business hotel but the rooms are very spacious. Access is so easy! When you arrive at Akasaka-Mitsuke station, its just across the street! Its huge building and can't miss it. There is a 7 Eleven downstairs too, and a McDonalds across the street. Such a great location for easy access to everything in Tokyo. Its only a stop or two away from Tokyo Central Station, meaning it doesn't take long to get to after a late flight into Tokyo. The hotel will also store your luggage for you if you arrive early, or have a late flight out of Tokyo. Be sure to try Tully Coffee and Hooters located downstairs.

Staying here for a week with my two teens. This is a great location with airport limousine stop. Staff was very helpful. Requested extra bed and no smoking room and got exactly what we asked for. Room is small as expected but the amenities were perfect. Short walk to metro, convenient stores and restaurants. It was just what we needed.

We booked at the last last minute this hotel because we didn't have a great choice. But we were really surprised by the quality and the good and convenient situation or this hotel.You may believe that , as it's a business area..it's far from everywhere but it's not the case..Just in front of the hotel you've got the underground( Akasaka Mitsuke) with 5 lines crossing.. So it's very convenient.Moreover.just a street ahead you find the area full of restaurants ( great choice and good ones( the ones we tried) plus a big Bic Camera, a pharmacy...The hotel by itself is excellent..we didn't have the choice about the room we wanted..Just a basic twin room was available..but it was roomy, and had, like in every Japanese room..everything you need : in the room and in the .bathroom. Plus free internet, TV.tel, a fridge, plusa special iron board we could use because we didn't really know how to use it etc..Friendly and professional staff trying to satisfy the customer..speaking English.They sent parcels for us to friends in Japan.( so worries about foing to a postoffice) Just down you find a 7/11!! Very ,convenient.The only "negative"point for a 4 stars..the room had a carper with a few stains..but it was really clean..otherwise.The buffet breakfast is worth the price with a great choice of Japanese or European food..excellentTo sum up it was a pleasant stay ina very good hotel well situated

Very easy to get to on the airport limo bus. Staff very helpful with baggage and checkin. We were given a smoking room on checkin which they quickly changed once we realized and our new room was excellent. Our only complaint was the hot water urn. We could not get it to boil and even the staff member had great difficulty. We finally got it to boil but never to pour. This is our only complaint. The Tokyo plaza is convenient and metro at your doorstep. The only other issue to be aware of is the airport limo bus finishes very early in the afternoon. Therefore you have to take a taxi to the central station and take the train. We had 2 large single beds and a lot of space. Small bathroom with bath tub and shower which is normal. Wifi is free you just need a new code each day.

As reviewed by many, this hotel is located directly opposite the Akasaka-mitsuke station, which allows easy access to the subway Ginza line and Marunochi line. It is also located in an excellent location that is different from the noisy district in Ikebukuro, Shinjuku or Shibuya. 7-11 and Tully's Coffee as well as some very cheap dining options right downstairs. Better restaurants can be found right opposite the street.

The hotel is located near metro station, and is a stop for airport bus. There is a big Mic Camera just opposite to it for shopping, and many restaurants are nearby. Less crowded and price is more reasonable compared to hotels near Shibuya. It is a quite a good choice for short stay in Japan. The room is well faciliated, and of reasonable quality, except the air-con did not work well during my stay. The room is small, not different from most hotels in Tokyo.

Stayed here 3 days before joining a cruise and 2 days post cruise as part of a package.We arrived around 11am after an overnight flight from London and wasting time at the airport waiting for the last person who should have been on our transfer bus who never showed.By the time we arrived at the hotel we were feeling very tired and was looking forward to a lie down before exploringWe were told the check in time was 2pm and would not budge on this.We checked our luggage in and went off to have a look around.There is a coffee shop a few doors up from the hotel and a McDonalds across the street. We walked up the street that runs down the side of McDonalds which led to a very lively district with small shops, restaurants and Bars.We returned to the hotel shortly after 2 and checked into our room.I had pre requested a non smoking room via email before we left the UK and this we got.Our room was at the front of the hotel and there was some restoration work going on with plastic sheeting over the windows preventing us seeing out. (Seems to be standard practice with cruise booking agents cheap rooms!)This was removed at the end of the working day.The bed was a little low but fairly comfortable.Bathroom was a little small but we did have a bath and I just loved the Japanese loos and the heated loo seat!Wifi was free but you had to get the code on a daily basis.Slept well. Although the hotel is on a busy main road we were not disturbed by traffic notice.We didn't eat in the hotel so can't comment on that.7/11 downstairs reasonable prices.Hotel is opposite the Metro and we had no trouble getting around using this method.Loved Japan everybody so nice and friendly towards us. Safe to walk around, no crime or unsociable behaviour and not expensive.Going back on another cruise around Japan next year. Can't wait.

Nice location with a metro station and many restaurants nearby. Reception was extremely efficient, rooms compact, very quiet and clean with free internet access in rooms. Staff were courteous and extremely helpful. My colleague left his PDA in a local restaurant and the concierge assisted him to retrieve it by calling and making all the arrangements on his behalf. Highly recommended if you are in Tokyo for a short break.

review_body: I stayed at the Excel Hotel Tokyu for a single night. The concierge was extremely courteous and check-in went very quickly. I had a non-smoking room on the 7th floor toward the back of the hotel, which had no view to speak of but was very quiet. The room was quite small by American standards but met my needs with only on exception: they have a system in place where you put your door's key card into a wall holder, which then switches on all the lights in the room (as well as the heat). However, when you remove the card it shuts off everything in the room except appliances connected via wall sockets. There seems to be no switch to turn off the ceiling light, so if you're reading in bed (using a convenient wall sconce with its own switch) and then decide it's time to go to sleep you have to get out of bed, remove the card, and then fumble back in the dark, as now no lights work (or heat!) Definitely a very strange system that had me wondering if I was doing something wrong.It should also be noted that while the room was quiet, the door itself is paper thin. Whenever someone was in the hall, or if a door opened, you could hear absolutely everything being said. My room was at the end of a hall so this was not a huge problem, but it's worth noting, particularly if someone was interested in a romantic getaway.
