review_body: Located just across the posh Akasaka-Mitzke district of restaurants, bars and much more, this hotel is a Jam. You get to the Marinoche subway line in 2 minutes which get you practically anywhere in the city. Service is great, rooms clean and well featured. I enjoyed it much.

I stayed here on a recent business trip and unfortunately did not do enough homework before my trip. More on this later.The hotel was excellent - clean, good service, good facilities especially for business travellers. The airport bus service to the hotel was very handy in both directions. The room was small, but that is fairly normal for Japanese business hotels, however the bed was good and the bathroom was excellent though I had trouble getting used to a heated toilet seat.The surrounding area is dotted with great tourist spots, and I wish I had done my homework beforehand. I had little time to do any sightseeing, but what I saw made me wish I had set some time aside for that. The hotel is within walking distance of the Prime Minister's residence and the Diet building, and a longer walk to the Imperial and Akasaka Palaces. Across the road is a great restaurant district as well as easy access to two subway stations.The room rates were very reasonable. I would highly recommend this hotel.

The hotel is superbly located, right above Akasaka -Mitsuke metro station, walkable for many business locations and pretty handy for tourism too via the metro. There are dozens and dozens of restaurants in walking distance.The hotel offers free wifi, all the toiletries you'll need, a surprisingly powerful shower and ipod speakers. Room is not massive and there is not a lot of storage space but like all Japanese hotels of this type everything is spotless. The staff are helpful and speak decent English. Now my official 'go to' hotel in Tokyo.

The hotel is modern, clean, and the staff are friendly and helpful, and their English is excellent. Our rooms were not ready when we arrived, so we left our luggage in safe hands and ventured out for lunch. To our delight we found a coffee shop virtually next door to the hotel, and across the road several streets filled with many places to eat, mainly Japanese food, which is what we were looking for. For the men in our group the huge Bic Camera store directly across from the hotel was a big plus. Hours were spent inside that store. Another plus was the subway/metro station beneath the store, offering us a multitude of destinations around Tokyo, and for very reasonable rates. We couldn't have chosen a better location for our stay. When we got back our rooms were ready. We were on a non-smoking floor, there was no hint of smoke, and it faced the main street, which gave us splendid views of Tokyo city lights at night. The bed was rather hard and our cleaning lady gave us, on request, padding for the mattress. The same can be said with our travelling companions in the next room. Our room was excellent. It was very clean, the fittings modern, and of an adequate size. Not huge by Australian standards but it was big enough for our needs. We were very happy with our rooms and the hotel as a whole. The Airport Limousine Bus stops right outside the hotel and offers an excellent way to come and go to Narita Airport. We would stay at this hotel again, definitely.

Stayed here on my first trip to Japan, not knowing quite what to expect. I arrived tired and jet-lagged, the staff were extremely friendly and helpful and although it was well before normal check in time a room was found for me. The rooms are a good size and very well equipped. The food in the restaurant was excellent and reasonably priced, though the drinks were a bit expensive. Breakfast was excellent with a huge choice. Public areas are spacious and well provided with informal meeting places. The staff weren't just friendly and helpful on arrival they remained as such throughout the 3 day stay.

Very good hotel and my single room was modern, comfortable and clean with coffee and tea making facilities. Good selection of bathroom stuff too as well as slippers and robe. Check-in easy and staff very helpful especially in the restaurant and at the excellent breakfast which has a good variety of both western and Japanese food. Hotel in a good location too within walking distance of many shops, restaurants and bars as well as the Metro station across the road. There is a shared reasonably priced efficient hotel limousine bus service to and from Narita Airport to this hotel dropping and picking up on the ground floor. Overall an excellent hotel to stay in and recommend to any visitor to Tokyo.

All the staff I encountered were very polite and helpful and spoke good English. The hotel itself is well situated for visiting Tokyo, with the Akasaka-Mitsuke Metro station a short walk away.My room was a single, non-smoking room on the ninth floor, which, although quite small, was adequate for my needs and away from the side of the hotel nearest the street, being therefore very quiet. The bathroom was well appointed, including the latest in in toilet technology, complete with heated seat and other functions.I only ate one dinner in the hotel and had a good meal from the a la carte menu - the usual buffet was unavailable that night, due to a corporate event. There are many other restaurants in the area, at all price ranges and styles. The breakfast buffet in the hotel was excellent, covering both local and international styles of breakfast menus.Overall I found this to be a comfortable and convenient base for my short stay in Tokyo.

We spent 8 night at the hotel. Spectacular breakfast, exciting dining options, tempting boutiques. Excellent area, bustling night life, lots of choices. But all the eating and shopping is done, it would have been so nice to go to work it out. Even just having a designated room to do yoga would have been great.

The Hotel has a good and courteous staff; services and room space is far better than compared to any hotel in Akasaka area. There are decent restaurants as well on the first floor.Hardly 1 min walk to nearest Akasaka mitsuke, ideal for Business travellers.

Tiny room and I was put in a smoking room without being asked. When I asked to be in a non smoking room the person refused and hung up on my face.Should have gone to nearby APA hotel same comfort half the price. Certainly won't make that mistake again.

Wonderful, relaxing stay for business. During the weekend the city across the street is very slow. Rooms were very nice size. The breakfast was more than enough. I wish I would have tried more of the restaurants attached to the hotel instead of across the street.

We stayed here during our last nights in Tokyo. It is very accessible as there are train stations are opposite the hotel and another one just next to it. ( depending on which direction you are heading ). Staff were friendly. The only drawback was it was central heating. ( we were there dec29-jan 2 ) . Therefore there is no way we could have adjusted the temperature whatsoever. We had to open the window to get some air through. Overall I would still stay here again.

We stayed here for a night after seeing friends during the national 3-day holiday. Actually this place has improved quite a lot from when I last stayed here maybe 7 or 8 years ago. At least some, maybe all, of the rooms have been updated and now justify the price. They used to be a bit pricey probably because it's a government/finance/entertainment area. The rooms are now more stylish, clean (which they always were) and modern.Check-in was very fast and efficient, but courteous and delivered with a smile). They were a little busy, but so pleasant they don't make you feel rushed (even though the whole process took less than a minute).Our double room was what they call "和のテイスト" (Japanese taste) room with a shoiji (wood/paper) screen window and other Japanese accents. However, slide the shutter in front of it before sleeping, to keep the room dark. Rooms at the back (sometimes) face onto trees which is nice. The room was an OK size by Japanese standards, but of course it'll be small if you're used to US/some European hotels. One nice thing about our room was that there was a small table by both bedsides (we always like to have mobile phone and water bottle there). There's also free WLAN. There's TV, not sure of the channel selection, we didn't check.We both slept OK, you get two pillows neither of which are especially soft so the harder one was relegated to the floor quickly. The beds are very comfortable in my view. It's a Simmons bed so should be good.The bathroom had a shower but no bath (I think this depends on room type) with a toilet on a raised section. Beware of that step if you get up in the night and forgot! The bathroom has a window between it and the bedroom, so set the blind to not allow light into the bedroom... Overall the room looks good, with brown/white striped carpet and dark wood/veneer. Facilities include trouser press, tea-making set, toothbrushes and some toiletries, of course air-con, and WLAN and power points (but only on one bedside table - hmmm). PC rental is available for 1500 yen per night. Note that there are several types of room so your room may vary a lot from the above. Price may also vary widely, and to get the best price you probably have to get a special rate from a Japanese web site. It's probably not allowed to name them here, but Japanese hotels have many very short-lived specials which don't get translated for the big international web sites. If you compare this hotel against other big chain hotels in the area (Tokyu is a big company) and they are in the lower price range, you got a good deal.The area is well served for transport, some of the orange-and-white Airport Limousine buses stop right in front (didn't see, just checked the bus website though). Akasaka-Mitsuke metro station (Marunouchi line, Ginza line) is just over the road. From the airport, if you don't know Tokyo, maybe take the above-mentioned bus. From Tokyo station, metro, or taxi is probably under 2000 yen if the luggage is heavy.Depending on price, this place comes back onto my list of should-check hotels due to (a) refurbished rooms and (b) sometimes reasonable pricing.

We lived in a room nearby the elevator and the bell of the elevator was really annoying so we asked if we might change for a new one and they did not hesitate at all for this request. In our opinion, this is a very good hotel for all kinds of travelers, especially those who would like to experience the convenience of the subway systems of Tokyo as the subway station is just across the street and there are 4 major lines across the station. Also, no need to take breakfasts in the hotel as there are various kind of restaurants around and take only a few minutes to those restaurants. The rooms are big enough for families. Friendly staffs were always smiling and did their best to satisfy our needs, we will definitely choose this one if there is another chance to visit Tokyo again.

I stay in this hotel with my wife as I have a meeting in Tokyo. It was a pleasant surprise for both of us as it was I first time in Tokyo & first experience with a small hotel room. The room & bathroom was so small but very decent. It was nice & clean too. The breakfast was very nice too. This hotel is very central the subway station is just across the road.

Rooms are very small,,,,beds are like sleeping on rocks,,,pillows are also very hard. Location not too bad. It,s better if you brush up on Japanese as there is not many English brochures to help you get around. Not a very helpful city.

The hotel is very conveniently located next to a Subway line and has access to many shops and restaurants. The rooms are relatively specious, of course relative to Tokyo, well features including Nespresso Machine + capsules, enough power outlets, comfortable bed and very clean. The staff is responsive, helpful and almost always available. Breakfast is very expansive at $25 and the quality is poor. The food is not fresh, coffee is watery and there is no choice - just black coffee. Not recommended - just cross the street to the many bakeries and you will have cheaper and better breakfast.

On our way to Karuizawa for skiing, we stayed 1 N at this hotel. Japanese courtesy and hospitality with humility plus sustained team work in facility maintenance makes the hotel standards world-best. This is a modern business hotel, with basic amenities -slippers, toothbrushes, shavers etc well stocked. Another great plus is the airport limo that stops right at the door step. Situated within Chiyoda-ku you can walk or take the subway to Ginza, Roppongi, Shinjuku. The only complaint that I have is the stuffiness of the room when the heater is on during the winter.

The rest of the world's hotels take note: Japanese hotels have the best service ever. The staff met us in the lobby with our room keys and collected our bags for delivery to our rooms...all that and no tipping, as good service is the norm and tipping is not customary. This hotel was conveniently located near shops and restaurants, and even had a 7/11 at street level.Our room was large with a desk area, closet, and refrigerator. Though the bed was firm, it was very large and comfortable enough, as were the (buckwheat?) bed pillows. The bathroom was massive, with a huge glass-enclosed shower and tub that contained the steam just in that section. My favorite part of staying at Japanese hotels is always the toilet--heated seats, built-in bidet, and bum-washer. Every hotel around the world should have these!The free WiFi worked well. The breakfast was excellent with many Western and Japanese choices--even miso soup.We would definitely stay here again the next time we're in Tokyo.

Business traveler, in Tokyo for a week. What impressed me most was the willingness of the staff to help me out with a variety of issues. Complex multi-room bookings, several restaurant reservations with assistance in finding ones that will offer vegetarian options. Adequate room size, by Japanese standards (small by NA standards). Break buffet was decent. Given they I am a vegetarian there were limited options, but in Japan I'm grateful to have any. Convenient located near a major subway intersection. Lots of nearby restaurants.

Can't fault anything really. The hotel was clean and modern, the food was fine, the location excellent. Close to the metro, which made it great to get around. I travelled alone so I took a standard room. If you will, too, be prepared for quite small rooms, though I'm not sure if it's average by Tokyo standards. There's a great advantage of the hotel being on the route of a comfortable limousine bus to the airport. Highly recommend using it because taxis in Tokyo are not cheap and the distance is not negligeable.

This hotel is nicely located where you can access to the metro within a minute and it's only 3 stops away to Ginza. And just opposite to the hotel, there is a BIC camera and lots of restaurants for you to choose from. Hotel is generally clean but the single room at the back is quite small and room tends to be dark due to sunlight being blocked by hotel wall. In terms of price, it's pretty reasonable. Even breakfast isn't included in my room rate, there are many cafes in the area and so you need not worry about finding a good place for breakfast.

Excellent location was what I feel for and the hotel delivered on this. Five Metro lines underneath the hotel. Lots of various restaurants in the neighborhood, however as it's a financial district it attracts the massage sales in every street/corner which may awkward.Aim for a room not facing the street as it is a bit noisy all day.

We had a bad experience at a nearby apartment so needed to book a night's accommodation at very short notice and as this hotel was nearby and some friends had stayed there the previous night we decided to give it a try.In the end we spent the remainder of our holiday there as the location was so convenient generally as other reviewers have said (and near to our Japanese relatives) Plus, although we only had the cheapest (and therefore smallest) type of room possible it contained all we required (they even squeezed a camp bed in to accomodate a third member of our party to keep our costs down) and it was very clean. The hotel was also quiet (despite refurbishment work at the front where we stayed) and the air conditioning was effective even when it was 33 degrees outside. There was also a Combini at first floor level which was very handy. The hotel staff were consistently good and typified the excellent customer service that we experienced in a variety of locations in Japan.Breakfast was via a buffet style voucher system and was OK but it did get a bit repetitive after a few days as it never seemed to change. Another minor point - a few more coathangers would have been welcome too.Overall though this hotel ticked all the boxes for us.

The area around Asakasa Excel is great for hole in the wall soba bars to fine dining. Hotel service was excellent, my son left his laptop in a taxi and the staff tracked it down and it was returned to us the next day. Rooms are a good standard and breakfasts very good too.

I stayed in a single occupancy room, so the size is small. Decent amenities. Service was good. Breakfast was average. Check-in and check-out time could be faster. I used laundry service and for a same day return (normal) they expect to call the bell to inform for 10 am pick up from the room, which is not clearly mentioned. If you don't call, even if you state as same day service in the laundry bag, they treat it as 4 hours return with 30% surcharge. I did complain and one of the staff personally attended to call the laundry only to find that they won't waive.In Tokyo, train station is very important. This hotel is 100 m from the Akasaka-mitsuke station which connects several connecting lines. 7-11 is located on the ground floor. Being one of the famous hotels in Tokyo, all guided tours, airport limousines has a pick up and drop off location from this hotel. There is BIC Camera store opposite and a large food court where you eat all types of cuisines.I took a guided tour after check-out and have to leave the luggage for two days until I board the limousine bus to the airport the following day. The staff was kind enough to take care of it. For the convenience of the location, I would recommend this hotel and will come back.

Great location with only 100 m to train station, shops and restaurants. located in central tokyo, good environment that can easily find anything you need nearby. I will recommend this hotel to families and friends.

Family stayed here 6 nights , nice hotel, rooms are big by Tokyo standard. Hotel is opposite of Akasaka metro station & is service by the A/P limousine bus. there is free wifi, a 7-11 on the ground floor ( grocery + an ATM that accepts bank & debit cards) . A Bic camera store is across the street (it has more stuff and a Pharmacy) the Excel hotel plaza on the 2nd level has a Hooters , Beer kitchen & other restaurants,the street Behind the bic store has a good range of small cafes, restaurants & bakery's . My main complaint is after flying 14 Hours and arriving at 7AM we were told NO Early check -ins( although we had paid for the day before), and were told to come back at 2PM. The staff was rude and unaccommodating. This hotel would get a better rating if they offered an early check in option (pain or unpaid) for passengers in situations such as us, (following our incident I noticed other guest who also arrived early and were forced to wait and sleep on the couches out in the lobby. This was a business-type hotel so this was not allowed and many were told by the hotel staff, including my wife, not to sit and sleep on the couches.) I give this hotel a standard + rating but cannot fully recommend it for those that fly in early morning

I had stayed here 4 nite for 3 person on 21th May, very nice hotel and I been have free upgrade to suit room. Have living and room saparate happy to stayed here, will recommended to my friends and will returned to stay in this hotel again if I visit tokyo.

Stayed there two times: November 2012 and November 2013. Both are for one week periods each.Pluses: tasty breakfast with lots of variety, good location: new Biccamera had been built just in front of it, good interior design, easy access to various locations even airport buses stop in front of it. Minuses: rather old, bad experience with a staff misunderstanding my country: indonesia with India. She insisted that my room had not been payed by my company due to it. After a couple of months there was a sorry letter from them anyway.

Location of this hotel is excellent, central and extremely well connected.3 metro lines are a cross the street, and another 2 a little walk away.Its relative proximity to the Imperial palace makes it a good option towalk along its moat to the kokusai forum and Ginza areaMy room was a moderate single. Upon check-in, I requested a good view roomand was told that my room was a high floor. I knew beforehand that roomseither face the modern tokyo akasaka modern cityscape or a kind of gardenon the backside.My room was a moderate single room, wide by Tokyo standards. It was facing this backside, with it's extremely high trees. I waslittle disappointed in the beginning as the room looked dull, but thisproved to be a big asset, and it was kind of a nice retreat in the hustleand bustle of Tokyo, with genuine bird singing every morning!Looking into the rooms map, I also realized that all the moderate singlerooms seem to be on this garden side.Fridge and expresso machine come very handy for any stay longer than acouple of days. Seven-eleven in the ground floor has all what you mightneed (now), grocery, stationary, umbrellas, cosmetics, lunch boxes thegenius of Japanese convenience store! And foremost: an ATM acceptinginternational bank cards, which is otherwise difficult to find in Japan,even in many big name bank ATMs. Staff was always courteous, willing, and able to speak good English(although I wanted to try my Japanese). High sense of safety prevails.Free wifi is included with daily cards which gives access for up to 3devices. It is little inconvenient, However to have to input login dataeveryday in 3 devices, as the duration of each login is only 24 hours.Moderate single room seemed a bit tighter than it's advertised 19 sqmeters, but it is surely a wide room by Tokyo standards.Airport shuttle bus from the door of the hotel is another big asset.Despite the last bus would put me in Narita almost 5 hours ahead of myflight, I opted for this option with my heavy suitcase.

We preferred to stay at this hotel because of its location and the hourly coach service facility to the narita airport. The hotel rooms are good, seems old but very well maintained. The staff is freindly and both check in and check out was very smooth and fast. It has good places to eat, supermarkets and the main subway station near by.

I guess given the location in Akasaka, a main business district and close to the subway station and entertainment district in the area (and less than a JPY 1,000 cab ride to Roppongi), this isn't a bad option. However, the room was so hot at night it was uncomfortable to sleep and when I woke up. Even though I had the air conditioning on the lowest temperature, it was too hot, and it was early April when I stayed there, so I do wonder what it would be like in summer. In addition, the bed wasn't that comfortable - in particular, the pillows were hard. The breakfast was very average. Also, I booked a non-smoking room about a month in advance, but there wasn't one available (maybe some of these complaints are a common problem in Japan?). Just ok - perhaps it would be worth forking out the extra money to stay in a western-branded hotel which doesn't have these problems. On the plus side, the room was very clean and tidy, the service was friendly and attentive, and as I mentioned the location is pretty good given the price is quite reasonable.

I stayed in the hotel 4 nights on my vacation in Tokyo. I enjoy travelling to rural areas like Kamakura and Kawagoe so I take the JR and subway a lot. The location of the hotel is located opposite of Akasaka station, which is right in the middle of Tokyo station and Shinjuku. I can easily get to Tokyo station to change to JR trains for rural areas, whilst I can just as easily get to Shinjuku for shopping and food. There is also a Bic Camera, a pharmacy (a must go in Japan), a street filled with restaurants (my personal favourite is a cafe named Choco Croc) and convenient stores all around. So if you just want a quick bite near the hotel, that is also available. there is also an airport limousine bus stpp right in front of the hotel. All in all, perfect location.Aa for the room, it is perfect for Westerners. It is quite big considering it is in Tokyo. There is also a nespresso machine and a bose sound system which is a nice touch. The air purifier/humidifier is also a god sent. The bed and pillow is very comfortable although the duvet is a bit heavy for spring weather. There is free wifi which is very nice. The bathroom is well equiped, with the ubiquitous heated toilet seat and a rainbath shower with massaging spray heads in the wall. All in all, excellent functionality.There is no free breakfast coupons as in most Japanes hotels but because I usually leave my room late in the morning anyways I prefer it like this so the coupons wont go to waste. The staff are friendly and spoke decent English. Excellent hotel. Will definitely recommend to others and will go back next time if I travel to Tokyo again.

Stayed at this hotel for 4 nights in early April, and it was a great way to start a 3 week trip throughout Japan.The hotel was easy to get to from Narita Airport. Though we had the option to take rail, there is the "Airport Limousine" shuttle bus that stops here among about 6 other hotels. After a long day of flying, an easy and direct option is appreciated.Staff was very friendly and certainly spoke enough English for us to get all settled with no trouble. Bags were delivered directly to the room.The rooms are decent sized for Japanese rooms - modern and clean. The bathroom was large and the shower had a fantastic 'rain-shower' style shower head, best of all the hotels we stayed at. Windows did not open, but each room had a cooling air purifier which kept the room cool provided you could figure out the buttons. I hear that windows in rooms on the street side do open.The hotel is very conveniently located right next door to the Tokyo Metro Akasaka-Mitsuke station, through which runs the Ginza and Marunouchi lines. From this central location, it was easy travel in all directions to other major stops, often with no transfers.Attached to the hotel is a 7-Eleven, which is a tourist's best friend in Japan. 7-Eleven ATMs are among the few that will accept North American bank cards, and the consistent selection of foods and amenities is very useful after a long day of traveling around. Several other restaurants are also located directly in Tokyu Plaza with a variety of styles.Across the street, the BIC Camera store offers a wide range of electronics and general goods (even a pharmacy), and the narrow streets around and behind the building offer a great range of smaller eateries, cafes, and sweet shops.As a first-time visitor to Japan, this hotel is highly recommended. #1 out of the 8 different accommodations we stayed at while in Japan. Location, nearby amenities, transit access - all top-notch.

Great location , next to the Metro Station , large hotel reasonable sized rooms fair size for a central hotel . Priced at a very reasonable cost. Beware as in a previous review about non smoking rooms, there seems to be a distinct shortage of them . We had requested non smoking rooms for our party of 6, 3 rooms . On arrival the reception desk stated we had not requested them, we remonstrated but did not have the proof to provide otherwise , their stance was not one I would like to see from a Japanese hotel in the future .

Great Location right in front BIC Camera store it's an 8 story shop and down below is the Ginza line Metrorail. Rooms are quite spacious and clean. Their staff are courteous but still a little bit language barrier.

Great place to stay. Across the toad from the metro train, if you stay here you don't need the JR train pass just need to get metro day pass which is 710yen a day. There isn't a JR line close by. The rooms were nice. Loved the shower, three different shower heads.Room was tidy and pretty comfy. Pillows were a bit hard.Right above the Ninja restaurant which was great. Also had a 7/11 which was useful. Really close to small alley ways with restaurant and bars.Really good place to stay.

Upon reaching the hotel, this hotel gentleman helped me push my luggage to my room where my husband had been staying for the past two nights. I was to join him after my trip. It is a decent room (small no doubt but expected in land scarce Japan), and a decent toilet with sink, heated toilet bowl and best of all, a standing shower cubicle! There are however big sized dispensers of shampoo, conditioner and shower gel available for use. What you pay is what you get. Having been in Tokyo before, I was prepared for the size of the double-bedded room, and as Japanese standards are always high in terms of cleanliness, I really had no fault to pick. The bed is firm, which I like. There is free wifi in the room. We were out most of the time and only needed a decent place to sleep. Its proximity to the train station makes travelling easy, and the food streets lined with eating places and restaurants just across provided a large variety of choices. There is the BIC Camera shop, it sells many things! Other than that, I do not see much in terms of shopping. There are the usual big grocery type of stores that sell everything! But it's in a nice quiet area. We spent Sunday morning having breakfast at St Marc and enjoying the street view from the cafe. The only gripe I would have was that the aircon did not seem to work and it felt stuffy in the room, my husband assured me it was like that but there was hardly any cold air emitting - difficult to breathe. (The next hotel that I went to did have cold air.) My respite was that after getting out the whole day to tire myself in order to get over jetlag, I did succeed in having a good sleep.

We stayed two nights along with tours to Disneyland. Local Shops nearby are neat. If you walk across the street, there is a Bic Camera Store open till ten in the evening. And turn left into a small street there is different bars and noodles sushi shops great for a night out drink and chat.

The hotel is nice, with small rooms of a standard Japanese size. Service was very polite and attentive. My only complaint is that all of the rooms reek of cigarette smoke. We had requested a non smoking room but upon arrival were given a smoking room. Upon complaining, the staff insisted that we did not request a non smoking room and politely showed us all of the rooms and let us pick the least stinky room. Needless to say, all of the 6 rooms we were shown reeked of cigarette smoke. We ended up choosing the room with the least stench however, this wasn't a great start to our trip in Tokyo. At the end of the day, the hotel should have been more up front about whether there were any nonsmoking rooms available. If you're sensitive to cigarette smoke, I would recommend choosing another hotel.

They gave me a very far room from the elevator with no window view! I requested to change room and front desk said you have to top-up to move to another same room with a view facing the streets.Location is perfect, just in front of train station.

I had two stays on business in November 2013. This comfortable business class Hotel is in a very accessible location close to subway station, loads of restaurants and in walking distance of the imperial palace district. Airport shuttle is available outside the hotel. Business class rooms have reliable wifi, desks and comfortable bedding and pillows. Efficient and quiet climate control too. Some traffic noise- but this is only to be expected given the location.Smart and clean restaurant on the 3rd floor offers limited international style and traditional Japanese dinner options. Greater range of choices at the breakfast buffets with fruit, pastries, cereals and hot western and traditional Japanese options.

hotel is very close to the subway station, and there are lots of restaurants available just in a few minutes of walking distance. hotel room is very clean and has a simple design. hotel provides an espresso machine which comes with nespresso capsules free of charge.

Stayed 4 nights. Taxi driver had no problems finding the hotel throughout my stay. Check in was on the 3rd floor. Didn't notice a doorman for most days.Check in was smooth. Was provided a room facing the main road, towards the subway station. The room was decently sized and clean. The bathroom had an in tub shower and clean. The hotel didn't provide individual packs of after shower gel, shampoo etc but large refilled bottles as part of it's green initiative.The hotel didn't provide any bottles of water in the room. There wasn't an in room safe either. The power sockets were all two prong only but they sent up an adapter when I requested for one.You can hear the traffic outside especially the emergency vehicles. There seemed to be at least 2 every night.Breakfast was on the 3rd floor. The spread was ok with a mix of Japanese and Western. There is a 7-11 on the first floor and a couple of restaurants in the attached mall and even more across the street.Check out was smooth. There were always plenty taxis just outside.

the trip planned by my freind, don't the rate.but the first impression of the room is small. the first floor connected to the convient store, very convenient. no wonder it's very clean, it's japan ! the most good thing was its very very clossed to the subway station. and very center of the city.

I will definitely stay in this hotel again when I return to Tokyo. The moderate twin bedroom my grandchild and I occupied was clean, mostly comfortable, restful and sufficiently furnished. We had 2 double beds. The bathroom has a strong-flow shower head, big bottles of of body soap, shampoo, hair conditioner. foam soap for hand-washing, and a wonderfully heated bidet with two kinds of water flow. We were given fresh towels, robes and slippers daily. A hair dryer and ironing board, which we had no reason to use, were available. Our room was cleaned, our beds were made up, and the tea pot was cleaned and replenished daily. We were given the option to choose our room-cleaning time on days we preferred to stay in. The hotel is conveniently located across a metro station, a few minutes walk to a shrine and shopping area, about 15 minutes walk to the Diet (Japanese Congress) building, and about 35 minutes walk to the Imperial Palace and Gardens. Though only a few members of the hotel staff spoke English, every staff member was solicitous.Suggestions to Hotel Management: The modified Japanese mattress on the beds could be made more comfortable by adding more soft and even padding. A thicker wall barrier could keep voices from a neighboring room from being heard in another room.

The average exp for this hotel is 8/101. Location for me is the best for me. 9/10 which is easy travel to shibuya ginza the fav places at Tokyo.2. The room is simple and nice. 7.5/103. The service is good. 7.5/10The shops inside the hotel are not really good. It has a nice view during the night. You can spend your night at the terrace enjoying the beautiful lights of the city. Its perfect spot!

We have stayed here a few times in the last 10 years and keep coming back due to the location of the hotel being so convenient. On this visit we stayed in January 2013, but I'm a bit behind in my reviews.We've had breakfast, lunch and dinner here over the years, the buffet is always generous and has both western and Japanese options.Nearby are fantastic restaurants, it is easy to find your way around the Akasaka area and access to the subway is just across the road. The Akasaka line and this station in particular is an easy change point to get across most of Tokyo.There is a convenience store at the base of the hotel, great for milk (not something featured in any Japanese hotels) and a quick meal or bento box.The bus to both Disneyland and the airport also leave from here. Downstairs is the famous (expensive, but worth it) Ninja restaurant, a must do in Tokyo if you can afford it (around AUD$220 pp last time we went).Yes, the rooms are small, but this is hotel accommodation in Japan generally. I love being supplied with toothbrushes, combs etcetera in the bathroom. Staff at reception are helpful and speak English.

It you are in Akasaka for business, this is conveniently located. The property is old, and it needs a lot of renovations (both the rooms, and the common areas). My main complain about this place is that it does not have a gym! For such a large hotel, it's crazy...

Stayed at Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu in Tokyo 2 weeks ago. We booked a air + hotel package through Cathay. According to the Cathay web site, the room is a semi-double room, however, we felt it's quite misleading as it's in fact a single room with the hotel standard. It was claustrophobic small room that we struggled to find space to open up our suitcase. Moreover, there is a window in the room but it's locked and cannot get any fresh air. (This might be for security reason since the room was situated at the back of the hotel building facing many government buildings. According to the hotel staff, window is locked in all standard single room.) We were told by the hotel staff that we could upgrade our room by paying hkd 100 extra per night but only smoking rooms were available. The hotel offers sandwich breakfast and breakfast buffet but they are a little pricy. There are some chain restaurants on the street behind Bic Camera which is located opposite to the hotel. Some open 24hrs and provide nice breakfast. We went to have breakfast at Seto Udon. Their breakfast set only cost 280 yens. Udon and the soup broth were very tasty. There are many restaurants in that street open till quite late and you can find several convenience stores in the area.We wouldn't mind staying at this hotel again since the location is quite good, but we would not book the semi double (standard single). Hopefully Cathay can get the true double room for the package not the "semi-double" = single room.

I stayed at this hotel for almost two weeks during a biz trip. In general the hotel is ok and the location is definitely a plus, moreover a Seven Eleven also available at the first floor.I suggest to cancel the breakfast and you will find many coffee shops nearby with better food for a more reasonable price.

Akasaka hotel location is definitely a plus. There 2 stations: across, and one next to the hotel.There is Bic Camera shop across the hotel, with all the items that you can buy easily. Behind the building, many restaurants that you can enjoy. Seven Eleven also available at the first floor.Being my second time in Japan, I can get accustom with the room size, especially for business hotel. Bathroom is always neat and clean - Japanese way of neat, which I love. The only downside was the bed, which was not very comfortable and caused me a back ache the next morning and days after. Sleeping quality is a disappointment. TV channels selection are a disappointment. The hotel could, at the very least, provide International channels like CNN, BBC, HBO or some international channel. Considering this is an International hotel for Business and Foreigners. No Complain for the breakfast and drinks. Must try the cofee..I would recommend this hotel for business due to its location and convenience. But definitely not for traveler with back pain... :-)

We stayed at this hotel for just one night during a tour. The hotel is ok and the room was a fair size (for Japan). We found that the hotel was bit sterile and kind of unfriendly but the staff were ok. Breakfast wasn't very good.

I've stayed here a couple of times and each time pledge it is my last - but after this stay it definitely will be. Booked a double bed non smoking but all I could get on check in was two twin sagging beds in a really foul smelling smoking room. The room was on the main road side and all night extensive roadworks including jack hammers kept me well awake. Breakfast is expensive and a non event.I travel a heap and am pretty easy but this place needs an overhaul big time. Also no gym.Why did I keep on coming back? -I'm not sure but that was the last time

The rooms are very clean and efficient. While the room faces the main road in the Akasaka area the noise was not an issue and the draperies block out all of the bright lights very well. While the breakfast isn't marvellous it is pretty consistent with other Japanese hotels. The location, right in the heart of Akasaka is very good. Walk across the street for a broad selections of dining and drinking including sushi to a pub. Overall a great spot.

Best about this hotel is it's location. The airport limousine bus goes directly there. The Tokyo metro is right there with several lines available. There are shops and restaurants nearby and the location is in an older, quieter section, but with lots of choices for activity. Service is excellent, except not many speak good English if that is what you need. The downside might be the very small rooms. Mine bordered a wall so I saw no daylight. Be sure to ask if you need a view. The hotel restaurant is much too expensive for me - $23 for breakfast. Fortunately there is a Tullys next door and Macdonalds across the street. Free wifi is helpful for business travelers. Likely better for business than a family vacation.

stayed in this hotel for 3 nights in October. The hotel is within the same building of Tokyu plaza, that's why you get the lobby on the 3rd floor. there are some restaurants and shops in the plaza that might be interesting but we didn't really find time to try any of them. the rooms are standard size not big but not too small either, very clean and wıth lots of accesories in the bathroom. The concierge was very helpful, all of their restaurant suggestions were just spot on, tell them what you want to eat for lunch or dinner, then they come with very good suggestions. Another positive side of the hotel is the location; there are very good restaurants from very casual to expensive ones just accross the street.Con side of the hotel is the breakfast; you need to be prepared for at least 15 min. of a queue to get in the restaurant which had very limited variety, noisy and smelly. we only had breakfast at the hotel on the first morning then avoided all the time.

I stayed at this hotel for a week, the location was fantastic! Great access to several subway lines, saved a lot of my time to visit my clients. Other than the location, you can't expect much...very tiny room, no safety box, needed to change wi-fi password every day. Good for business trip, but not for my private one. The front desk clark, Ms Sato provided me with impressive hospitalities. Hope other staffs will keep the same standards as hers.

Access to two metro lines. Typical for Japanese Hotels: Clean, Excellent Service, A/C a little warm (for Hong Kongese preferring 23 deg C). Atypical for Japanese Hotel: Room is good size. We booked through a flight + hotel package. Our 5 people party got allocated two adjacent rooms. Our 3 people room has a folding bed and the 2 people room is just as big. Excellent vlue for money.One of the few options in Tokyo that offer 3-people rooms.

The best thing about this hotel is that it's very near 2 metro stations (2-5 min walk) which gives you plenty of option to go to lots of places in Tokyo. It's really an excellent location! 7-11 was literally just downstairs and it's very convenient to grab an early breakfast or late supper. A fleet of taxi are almost always ready downstairs or across the road, so if you prefer taxi, you shouldn't have problems at all.We stayed as a family of 5 and booked 2 moderate double rooms. Will not recommend this to people coz it's pretty cramped to squeeze 3 people in a queen bed, unless you're going to bring your own sleeping bag (pls check with the hotel beforehand, sometimes they have extra bed). On our first night, the air-cond was not cold and we slept without blanket, but the subsequent 3 nights were fine. No cigarette smell and everything is quite clean. The bathroom is rather small but well equipped with large bottles of soap, shampoo and conditioner, which are diligently replenished. Can't compare this to other hotels in Tokyo but I will definitely consider staying here again the next time I come.

We stayed there for 2 night and the hotel is located conveniently at akasaka metro station. We got dropped off from the airport directly to the hotel and it cost is 3000 yen per person but still considered reasonable as we had so many luggages.Hotel room is spacious compared to other hotels in tokyo, queen size bed and the shower was amazing. The highlight was the nespresso machine in the room and complementary pods in the room.The location is very convenient as it is the interchange to different lines such as tokyo station, shinjuku, shibuya and the metro station is right opposite to the hotel.Will definitely stay there again if I ever visit tokyo in the near future.

The best part about the Akasaka Excel Hotel is for sure that it is literally across the street from the Akasaka-mitsuke station, which directly connects to all the major stops in Tokyo that you may want to visit: Shibuya, Shinjuku, Ginza, Tokyo Station, Ueno, Asakusa, etc. The hotel itself is clean and the staff are friendly. Of course, the rooms are small but it is to be expected if you go to Tokyo. We stayed in the standard room, though I saw some of the higher grade rooms and they a lot more spacious. The amenities are great - big bottles of shampoo, conditioner, and body wash as well as hairbrush, toothbrush, razor, etc. There is a huge 711 on the ground floor!The only downside I would say was that they couldn't give us a non-smoking room, though honestly it wasn't a huge problem even though I hate second hand smoke. We heard some 'noises' from neighboring guests in the evening one night - good for them I guess. We just drowned them out with the TV.

The location of the hotel is a definite plus on any scale, you have 2 Metro Stations and a lot of bar/restaurants nearby like Hooters :D, which is conveniently located right next to the hotel.We booked a semi-double room, the rooms were clean and small but good enough as we spent most of our time roaming around Tokyo. The decorations in the room were simple but we had a good view watching the sun rise. The hotel staffs were very helpful and friendly. This place definitely caters more to business travelers but for anyone else, this place is good since the hotel's location is very convenient.

The room was clean, all toiletries are available, free wifi and on walking distance of CITI Bank ATM. Underground on walking distance and nearby the Imperor Gardens. Also within walking distance of restaurant area. People are very friendly, they help you or they seek help from others!

Worth the cost!!!! Really great location Cross the street and your in the heart of Akasaka,Tokyo.. Superb location for business and leisure travellers, easy access to market and great shopping places like shinjuku,Ginza n much more thru metro,bus and taxi...located just nearby the Business district and nice pubs n restaurants.... hotel's Restaurants are also superb...Good healthy multi cuisine breakfast but having least options for vegetarians. If you are a non vegetarian, have lots of great options....Breakfast - they have everything - power up! Staff,They are very, very polite and and warm. English - some of the staff speak English or at least a little, even if they do not speak it, they will steer you towards someone that does... Rooms are well equiped with all amenities and nobody is required to carry anything from the toiletries from home. Simply the good and economical property to stay in the heart of Japan.

I stayed here for four nights in total. A double room comes in a range of formats, the best are very good indeed, the cheapest are cramped, the furniture worn and the worse for a great deal of wear. The real drawback though to this hotel is breakfast. Every single guest has to form an orderly queue and this at times can be as long as the width of the hotel. On arriving at the front of the queue, which can take up to twenty minutes, one is escorted to a table then abandoned to work out how to join the rugby scrum for breakfast. On a busy day it is chaotic and very un Japanese as it is badly organised. There are better hotels in Tokyo.

Room Size - not as small as people are making it seem. The room is VERY comfortable in size, so do not worry on that front. It is actually very close to the size of a normal hotel room in the US (we got the double bed room).Toiletries - you do not really need to pack much. They have huge bottles of shampoo, conditioner, body soap, face soap and hand soap. Leave those at home. They even have mini brush, 2 toothbrushes, 2 razors, one hair tie and a shower cap. Save the room in your suitcase.Air Conditioner - keep your key in the holder by the door to keep the AC running. If you leave the room and remove that key (aka, do not have a spare) your room will heat up. What do we suggest if it still isn't cool enough for you? Go across the street to BIC Camera, go up to the 6th floor and purchase a fan from their huge assortment. We got ours for ~$9 and plan to leave it here. Worth the cost!Breakfast - they have everything - power up!English - some of the staff speak English or at least a little English. They are very, very polite and, even if they do not speak it, they will steer you towards someone that does.June Travel - yes, it did rain a little here and there but it was refreshing.

Really great location Cross the street and your in the heart of Akasaka.. Restaurants galore.. This is classic Japan. If your pillow sensitive be aware they are ( and the bed is ) HaRd But the hotel itself is nice.. Staff great For business can't beat it for the price. Always have Internet specials Book there and save $ big time

Stayed 4 nights in mid June with my wife in a Moderate Double room.Room size is about right, at least enough for our 2 big luggages. In Tokyo this is really spacious.Opposite to Akasaka Mitsuke metro station and just next to Nagatacho station. In fact they can be getting through. My opinion is if it is a rainy day, you can come out at an exit (forgot which one) from Nagatacho which is just at the right hand side of the hotel, so you even need not to take your umbrella out and reach the hotel's 2nd floor, which is part of a shopping arcade. Hotel lobby is at 3rd floor for checking in.You can reach nearly most of the places in Tokyo from these two station, say Shinjuku, Skytree, Ueno,... as they covers 5 different metro lines.Above Akasaka Mitsuke station there is a new Bic Camera. Behind this station there are hundreds of restaurants for you to choose. Fastfood or jap noodles or hotpot or bbq... Spending varies.On the 1st floor there is a 7-11 convenience store. Many stores also there opposite.Fascinating and refreshing shower system inside bathroom, rainfall shower head with pressure massage heads.Bed is clean and good. Wired and Wifi internet are both very fast.As many of reviewer said, the air-con is not enough cool in summer days.Never try the espresso machine (using capsules), so no comment.Staffs at front desk are very helpful, with fluent speaking English.

A perfect hotel for business and leisure travelers, just opposite to several malls and dining options. This hotel is very well situated the Subway and Metro rails ie Akasaka Mitsuke station. The breakfast is fantastic and the top floor restaurant and bar by Nadaman is ecstatic.

It is a very nice hotel, with a very helpful staff. It is located at steps of a metro station, and it is near of many interesting locations in Tokyo, such as the palace gardens and some shrines. If you want the windows of your room to open, ask for a for a front room.
user_name:
darwinsail
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: 由本地的朋友代订的酒店。非常方便，对面就是地铁站和食街。有很多地方可以吃饭。整个地区晚上安静、干净。房间不大，但是很干净。浴室面积还可以。没有身体乳提供。水比较大。房间里有wifi，速度很快。带电开水壶和咖啡机。总之，会再住和推荐给朋友。Booked by a local friend for us. It's convenient, just opposite to the metro station, and a food street. Many places to eat. The area is quiet and decent as well. The room is small, but very clean. The size of bathroom is fine, no body lotion. The water is strong. With in-room wifi (quite fast), hot water kettle, and coffee machine. In general, will stay again and recommend to friends.

There is a limo bus from the airport to the front door of the hotel. It costs about $30(US) per person. It took about 1 3/4 hours for the trip.The hotel has numerous restaurants around it, and the subway station to all over Tokyo is across the street.The room was a modern, comfortable room with a good mattress, excellent bath tub/shower, plenty of soap, shampoo and conditioner and nice amenities. Had the standard heated toilet seat with built in bidet.Large TV, but with limited English channels.Buffet Breakfast was expensive($22) but very nice, with both western and Japanese foods. The first night we ate at the Hotels Dinner buffet which was excellent, it cost about $44, but was outstanding if you want western food.

I stayed at this hotel for 2 weeks every month for 7 consecutive months (October 2012 to May 2013). The purpose of my trip was obviously work, and my role as a software developer will give you an idea of my personality type (perfectionist, tidy, punctual, orderly...etc).The staff were fantastic - typical of Japanese hospitality service.The room is good for the price (I got a corporate rate of JPY16000/night). Free WIFI in the room, and connection by LAN cable in the room a bonus - great for SKYPE and watching online TV/movies through laptop connected to TV (I supplied my own HDMI cable). The room has tea/coffee machines but I never used them. The bathroom (with shower over bath) is typically small especially for someone 185cm tall. More expensive rooms have a walk in shower (would have been nice!!). I had no problem with the air-con during winter, but did not experience a summer there. Nights can get noisy with sounds from neighboring rooms and/or sirens on the main road outside - but not that frequent. Good wardrobe space. I always ordered more hangers for all my business shirts. Didn't use the hotel laundry service as I preferred to save money and use the laundromat 5 min walk away, and then iron my clothes myself (using good equipment from hotel)When it comes to food I'm very much a foodie - expect high standard at reasonable prices. IMO the hotel does not offer this. I ate dinner at the main restaurant many times only because I was using loyalty points, and even then I struggled to find good value. I had the full buffet breakfast once just to experience it, and at JPY2500 IMO it's not good value for the limited range of food on offer. I only enjoyed the scrambled eggs and toast (but I'm really fussy). The bacon is not what I'm used to in Australia. Not sure what it was so did not touch it. The range of fresh fruit was limited to 2, but not surprising given the cost of fresh fruit in Japan. For breakfast I was happy with my Weetbix I brought over from Australia, eaten in my room with my own bowl and spoon. But if you're into food you need not worry - within 5 min walk across the road you have everything you could want at reasonable prices - japanese, ramens, sushi, kebabs, subway, pizza, pasta, turkish, steak, indonesian, chinese, pubs, coffee, even a McDonalds and Hungry Jacks...etc,etc. Just brilliant. It really is food heaven. Exceptional lunches for JPY1000, and dinners for JPY2000. Much more expensive places also if you are after something special. Downstairs in the basement is a great cheap Italian place which was also great value. Don't try the Hooters - burgers I would only feed to my dog. I tried one and the bun was still cold (from fridge) in the middle. You go to Hooters for the novelty of the girls dancing around.The location is great because of the access to the subway across the road, and also the food choices. It is also about 25 minute walk from the nightlife district of Tokyo (Roppongi)l. I did this many times on Fri/Sat nights after the last train (which is around midnight). It is very safe to walk the streets in the early hours of the morning.For those interested in fitness the hotel does not have any facilities because they refer you to a gym in the building next door. I payed around JPY5500 for 2 weeks. Other rates are available. It is not a big gym, but has the basics and does the job.Overall great place. If it wasn't I would have chosen elsewhere....

I joined this hotel for our group tour. Rooms were ok typical of Japan compact but what impressed me is the resto at 8th floor very good Japanese food and breakfast in this hotel is also excellent especially sice hotel is centrally located

We have stayed at Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu for 4 nights during our visit to Tokyo in late April. We were very happy with it. The room size is very good, well equipped with amenities. The staff were very helpful and friendly. We enjoyed the breakfasts. There were selections of Japanese and American breakfast. The location is excellent, subway station just across the road. There were plenty of restaurants around in just a very short walk. Just one minor point, the a/c in the room got quite warm at night. We definitely will stay there again.

Covers everything you may need from a hotel.1. great location, has a station just opposite the hotel, food restaurants and convenience stores are just across the street, gindako takoyaki cripsy creme etc2. Rooms are great, just what you will expect from a hotel3. The airport limousine bus stops here, easy access and departure from the airportBeen here 2 - 3 times, all in all experience has been great.

We stayed here for two nights and were satisfied. We got an upgrade to two rooms from one twin and a free breakfast as a perk. The rooms were typical Japanese: rather small but well equipped and maintained. I fought with light and AC control a bit - until I found out that everything can be controlled from a panel at bedside. Staff was professional, breakfast quite rich, including both western-type and local food. However, waiting in a queue in front of the breakfast room can take few minutes in peak times. The hotel location is hard to beat, several underground lines within few steps and many lively small streets just a block away, if you like walking around, especially in the night.The only major flaw was that my room was not made up at all when I had put the "Don't change the sheets" sign at door.

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights as part of a wider trip around Japan. The location of the hotel is excellent, breakfast is good and the free wifi is certainly a perk. However, our room was unacceptably hot and we were unable to turn the heating down which prevented us from sleeping well. There are two restaurants, the top floor restaurant and bar is pricy but very nice. The 3rd floor restaurant is more basic and we found their interpretation of western dishes weird at best.
user_name:
Ruth S
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Great location, with 2 metro stations (5 lines) on the doorstep, making it easy to navigate such a vast city. Always plenty of taxis outside too. Hotel itself in the Tokyu plaza, with a few shops and restaurants for all tastes. More just across the road. The hotel is modern and clean. All staff friendly and polite, especially the concierge who helped us with a number of things, including a helicopter flight over Tokyo at night (a must!). All staff spoke good English. Upgraded to a superior double; comfy bed, good facilities (including a super loo!).

Never stayed in this hotel, but went to Excel Shibuya several times and then Otani and Cerulean. The hotel is a perfect location and overall quality is very good. Wi-fi works great and it's free, while on higher level hotel you have to pay! Breakfast is pretty good but not at the level of others. For same price (just 200 yen difference) you can have a completely another level buffet with garden view at the Otani, for example, within 5 minute walking distance. The convenience store downstairs with ATM can prove very useful. Around lots of restaurants and alternative places for breakfast. All in all I will consider again this hotel for my next visit to Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel for 2 nights as part of a tour of Japan. We had a twin room. It was very small with limited space for 2 suitcases which we were living out of during the tour. Pillows are very hard. Bathroom very small. This appeared to be the norm. Plenty of hot water and toiletries. Breakfast was poor. Small restaurant so you need to get there early if you want breakfast before you set off in the morning. Food always lukewarm at best. Doesn't get replenished very quickly when it runs out. Was very conveniently located for getting round Tokyo. Underground station directly opposite hotel. Staff were always polite and helpful.

I have been a semi-regular guest at the Tokyu for several years and it is a solid hotel. Close to everything you need, with a great staff and nice rooms. When in Japan, I like a smaller room, or should I say, an appropriate-sized room (I found the palatial rooms of the Grand Prince a sickening waste of space). Tokyu rooms are what you need and no more. The value is decent, though Tokyo could probably demolish 20% of its hotels and turn the land back into parks.

I visited Tokyo for a few days of vacation. I needed somewhere conveniently located for meeting up with friends and shopping.The Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu Tokyo fit the bill. It is across the street from the Akasaka Mitsuke subway station, with the Nagato-cho subway station also around the corner. This puts you within a short walk of 5 subway lines, which makes it easy to get around to most anywhere in Tokyo. In addition, there are tons of restaurants and bars in the immediate Akasaka and Akasaka Mistuke neighborhoods.The hotel rooms were about average for a Tokyo business hotel. The room size was mediocre. The bathroom does look recently remodeled, which is a plus. The Nespresso machine in each room and memory foam pillows are also nice touches.

I stayed at the hotel for 2 nights during my visit to Tokyo, and it was perfect. I was a little worried after reading some reviews online about the hotel for its rooms being too small. I stayed on the 8th floor, in the ladies area, in a moderate single room, and it was perfect. Room size is great, plenty of room to walk around, good closet space, bathroom with tub. Quiet room as it is facing the back instead of the street. Most importantly, it's in a very convenient location, literally right across tokyo metro station Akasaka Mitsuke, arund 90 mins from Narita Airport on Keisei main line limited express. The hotel is in a businss district, therefore it's less busy but just a couple stations away from Ginza and other areas. Hotel itself is surrounded by lots of restaurants, coffee shops and convenient stores. Hotel staff very efficient and accomodating. I booked the room on expedia, got a great 50% off rate. Wrote the hotel with my special request of non-smoking and room on ladies floor. Got a reply the next day confirming all the requests. I am very happy with the hotel, and definitely will return to it. Highly recommended.

We (3 girls) stayed in a triple room in the Asakasa Excel Hotel Tokyu recently on the way home from our ski trip. The room wasn't huge, but it definitely accommodated the three of us comfortably. The beds were cosy and the bathroom was big, with a lovely hot, well pressured shower. The hotel is located about 2 minute walk from the Asakasa-mitsuke metro line which has you in Ginza, Shinjuku or Toko stations in a couple of minutes. There is also a Tokyo Hooters nearby :-)...or for he more discerning tourist, the hotel is located across the road from a little restaurant district with plenty of different cuisine's to choose from. We got a pretty good deal through Booking.com - room rate was about $AU200/ngt for a triple room so, given the location and cleanliness of the hotel, I thought this was VERY reasonable for Tokyo. Front reception staff all spoke very good English, and were also happy to entertain my average-at-best Japanese. Friendly and polite like all Japanese people!There is also a 7-11 located in the entrance to the hotel which is great for avoiding those minibar fees.Would definately recommend this hotel to family and friends!!

Stayed february 2013 for 2 nights in a "superior double" room.This hotel is well located in the busy but spacious Akasaka district, a few steps away from Akasaka Mitsuke metro station (and less than 10 minutes away from Nagatatcho station), with plenty of restaurants (and convenience stores) around, ...You can reach the hotel by the "Limousine Bus" from the airport.Standard business type of hotel, no particular "japanese design/feel".Free wifi provided and operational.Rooms are small, as often in big japanese cities, but it's OK unless you come there to live inside the room. The bathroom on the other hand is really on the small side, even by Japanese stantards. My room was quite clean (spotless bathroom) and the overal hotel environment seems to be that way.Reception is a bit understaffed so be prepared to queue a bit for check-in and check-out if you do that at a busy time.Breakfast is really sub-standards both in terms of choice and quality especially with the hefty price tag unless you get it within a room package. So I strongly recommend you skip the breakfast there and get it outside in one of the coffee shops around.All in all I find value for money to be below standards. For 1000 JPY more you can have a room at the nearby New Otani which has much more class and larger rooms. I guess it all depends on the rate you can get at the time you inquire.

Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu is situated in one of Tokyo's central business districts.As far as location and convenience are concerned, this hotel certainly ranks high, in my opinion. The Akasaka-Mitsuke train line is across the road from the hotel. On the same stretch of the road you will find isakayas, restaurants, pubs, cigar bars, and the ever omnipresent MacDonald's. For those who hunger for a midnight snack, there's a 7-11 at the basement of the hotel itself. How's that for convenience. The hotel room is rather tiny. I would recommend you give the Double Room a miss if you want space to move about amidst your barricading suitcases. Maybe opt for a Twin Room instead. And don't bother sliding open the window hoping for a view. The 4th floor Double Room window looks out to a backlane! And I reckon the walls and doors could be better soundproofed. Quite often you can hear conversations in the corridor outside. But there are nice touches aplenty really. There is free Wi-Fi connection, complimentary Nespresso pods for those who need an instant pick-me-up in the morning. And then there's this spiffy sci-fi shower adjustable head that directs jets of water on your head and all over your body. Brilliant. And any Japanese tourist would know by now, the ubiquitous Toto washlet is heaven sent. Especially the heated seat on a bitterly cold morning. Based on its location alone, I would strongly recommend this hotel for both business and leisure stay.

Location near subway with good wifi connection though room is small. Very clean and 7 eleven is located just downstairs. Subway is just opposite so convenient to go to anywhere. Booked full day trip with pick up services - grey line tours and no need hassles to look for other day trip services

Good hotel, (overly) well-appointed, good location, very good bed, good plumbing, OK breakfast, friendly staff, but not quite right either for business (no desk/work space) or for pleasure (far too cramped). Hotels in Tokyo frequently (usually?) have small rooms, but this one was ridiculous. I have been in bigger closets -- even in Amsterdam. One literally had to sidle crab-like simply to move around the bed. It was a shame the room was so tiny, because otherwise the hotel had everything going for it. Location (both for transport and for restaurants) was excellent. Limo buses from both Tokyo airports stop literally outside the front door. The internet connection was good. The room was well-appointed. But I would have happily given up the expresso machine, the Bose stereo speakers and the trouser press for a couple of feet of "desk" space. (I use the term advisedly: the "desk" was a ledge under the (sealed) window that started out the depth of my laptop and tapered down to just four inches.) There was neither a closet in which to hang clothes nor a chest of drawers in which to put clothes. (True, there was a rail on the wall that had four hangers. Let's see: one for an overcoat, one for a suit jacket, one for a shirt, one for trousers. (And, no, getting more hangers was not an option. The rail would only hold four hangers.) That may work for a one-night stand/business trip, but is wildly inadequate for someone like me who came to Tokyo to work for a week. Don't get me wrong, I am happy living out of a suitcase. The problem is that there is no place to put a suitcase. True, there is one of those folding suitcase stands, but that didn't get around the lack of floorspace upon which to open it. I assume the more costly suites have more space, but for the life of me I couldn't figure out who the room I had was designed for. Presumably businessmen use it. Certainly it wouldn't work for couples or a family.
+loved the hotel , the location is great just near the akasaka mistuke station ,The room size is ok compared to other hotels-it was noisy u can hear everything from outthe belows was not comfortable
