review_body: This hotel worked out very well for my first visit to Japan. It was across the street from a Metro station and had a lively area nearby filled with plenty of restaurants. We did not spend much time in the room, but for sleeping the beds were very comfortable. We did not spend much time in the neighborhood, as we were more into sightseeing and I think this neighborhood is more about great restaurants. The room got a little hot at times, we kept the window cracked in December most days, but I found that every place I went in Japan ran a little warm so I think they just like heat. I found the hotel to be extremely accommodating, I needed an American style iron, and one was delivered. My husband needed a converter for his laptop, they had ones at the front desk that you could borrow. I wanted to mail postcards. They mail them for you at the hotel, and you just pay them for the postage! Small conveniences like this go a long way for someone like me. We did the breakfast buffet 3 out of 6 mornings at the restaurant- it had a really nice spread of both Japanese and Western style food. My only complaint would be that they served the exact same things at the buffet every morning, (but everything was delicious). The Airport Limousine (which is actually a bus) includes this hotel on their stops, which proved very convenient for getting to and from Narita AIrport. If you want a hassle-free stay with many conveniences I think it's a good option. And I'd say it's upscale but not super fancy, I was very comfortable here.

Pros: The hotel is in a great location near the Akasaka restaurant area and just across an Metro station which is very convenient.The rooms are in great condition, there's an airport shuttle going from the hotel 7-8 times a day and the staff is very kind and helpful.Cons: for some reason, it seems the place had no gym/pool or any way to keep a normal workout routine. Very disappointing.Breakfast buffet wasn't very exciting as well. The pastry seemed to be dry for some reason and the rest was ok but nothing more than that.

The rooms are quite small yet clean and tidy; with free wifi -- quite convenient for a business traveler. Tried the restaurant at the hotel, quite good but ridiculously expensive -- you might as well walk across the road where there are tonnes of eateries available or Hooters on the other end of the hotel complex :) We were on the 6th floor, hardly any noise as mentioned in other reviews. Very nice sleep.Getting around is easy -- a taxi stop in front of the hotel, and right across is the Akasaka Mitsuke metro which is also connected to the Nagatacho metro (400-600m).

This hotel is very nice, clean, the staff is very helpful. It is perfect for a business trip of few days in Tokyo. Opposite the tube station for your wonder around in discovering the city.The rooms are small but very clean, tidied and quiet.The restaurant at the 3rd floor has very good food and very nice people looking after you. At the ground floor you always have taxis waiting to have the next customers so there is never a hassle to find one.Wifi is free so perfect to communicate for work, your family and friends.

Stayed here as part of an organized tour so cannot comment on value. Well situated across the road from Akasaka Mitsuke metro station and behind the station are numerous restaurants,including an excellent Italian. Rooms are well sized by Japanese standards and free Wifi in the rooms is a bonus. Warning! do not eat in the hotel as ludicrously expensive-cost equivalant of A$32.00 for two cappachino. Air conditioning difficult to adjust in the room.

We stayed here for two nights and it was very convenient right across from the metro with Ginza line and the red line. You can get to the major attractions from here. A lot of food places right across the street. We ate at a Korean restaurant right across the street and it was wonderful. Getting to Tokyo station was also very easy with the red line. The room is small but compared to Japanese standards, it was pretty big. Getting to Shijuku, Shibuya were all very easy. We walked so much that we fell asleep right away and hence the noise mentioned by the other reviewers did not bother us. The staff were extremely useful in suggesting shopping places to meet our needs.

Pretty central location, acceptable prices and agreeable rooms. Friendly staff too. The "10-minute breakfast" is a bit of a joke but, then again, I had the room at a substantial discount so I'm not complaining.

Stayed in the Akasaka Excel for two nights. It is clean and the room was comfortable and well proportioned. It is also in a convenient location right next to the metro and with hundreds of restaurants and bars right on the doorstep.However I wouldn't return simply because the walls were really thin and I could hear everything going on in the adjacent rooms. This included the people next door using the toilet and watching pornographic movies!

1. Smell... Smoking rooms are located in the same flower with non smoking rooms.If you really do not mind of smoking... may be it's OK. However if you are looking non smoking room, DO NOT STAY. EVERYWHERE SMOKING SMOKING SMOKING!2. Roach... BIG ROACH! Very BIG! I asked to front to replace, and they just did their service. However if roach is in a room, how many roaches are in the building?

The hotel is situated right opposite to the Akasaka Mitsuke station. There are a number of restaurants and bars within walkable distance from the hotel. The room was clean and comfortable but small with just enough space for the bed and a small table, not much of moving space though. The room had a LCD TV, coffee machine and all toiletries provided and a good internet connection. The attached bath had a bidet toilet which is very convenient.The buffet breakfast was ok. Good sea food options available.There could have been more options for vegetarians / non-eaters of sea food.The staff were helpful and could speak in English.

This hotel has full marks for everything. The limo bus (3000 yen pp) stops at the hotel, efficient friendly staff at check in, great and squeaky clean standard double room (small but big for Japan) so well appointed that you would not notice the space issue, all amenities in the room (i could only think 2 missing items - cloth drying line and sewing kit) complete with espresso machine and kettle with complementary tea, green tea and coffee. It's location is amazing, being just the other side of the road from Akasuka Mitsuke station. It is also close to endless number of restaurants, Citi bank ATM, Post Office, exchanges, star bucks, taxi rank etc etc. I preferred the standard room in the back overlooking the garden to the superior room overlooking the road which is a bit more spacious and has a bath tub, but was glad i did not miss out on the shower in the standard room. The hotel also provides a great wifi, all toileteries including razors and hair brushes and has a tour desk at the reception every day of the week. I paid 38000 yen for 3 nights, but did not regret it. Toilet and Shower was one of the best i have ever used.

I have stayed for five days. The location is very easy to find,just opposite from the akasaka mitsuke station, at the heart of Tokyo Metro line -Ginza line & Marunouchi line that easy to link up the most famous place for visiting.The room is quite big of the japan standard, well- decroation with nature tone, not grand but really comfortable.U can find all u need in room; modern iron, BOSE speaker, simmons mattresses, LCD TV,coffee machine on a coffee table! Of coz the shampoo , hair blower are provided.Btw, the staff were not really helpful and nice i met at the front table, some of them can speak in basic english, just simple english.Overall, this hotel is value for money!

If booking a single, pay the 1000 yen to upgrade to a double. The single room's size combined with the low ceilings is utterly claustrophobic. And ask for a room facing the street since those facing the back only have very small angled windows (no windows are allowed to look out onto the government buildings next door). Negatives: Worn surfaces, stains, and less than clean carpet. Children playing loudly in hallway at 11:30 pm. An unpleasant odor lingered throughout the room and lobby areas.Luggage was about to be sent by staff to the wrong forwarding hotel. The best thing this hotel has going for it is the comparatively low price, but don't book through Expedia -- major hassle cancelling one night's stay despite following their stated policies.

Single rooms are small but in comparison with other Japanese hotels (In Tokyo ) I'd say its good enough. Wc is again typical for japan, which could really do with a shower instead of the bath tub... Basically its just bed & breakfast.Breakfast then is buffet or ala carte american.... Buffet has no fried eggs. Only scrambled eggs.... And omelette.

Perfect location with access to three different subway lines and yet still very close to both ginza and Shinjuku. Beds are comfortable (also have memory foam pillows) and bathrooms are smartly designed. Showers have a rainfall/massage type shower so it's perfect for unwinding after a long day walking in Tokyo. Rooms include an espresso machine, 32 inch LCD TV and Bose speakers. I got a lot of use out of the bose speakers with my ipod. Service is incredible and there are native English speaking staff members on site as well as plenty of English speaking Japanese staff. There is also a bus stop right outside the hotel for both Narita and Haneda airports. Narita is quite far and the price they were asking for the bus was about average. Haneda, on the other hand was a little overpriced IMO, but it is still very convenient.There is a convenience store located on the basement level of the hotel building so you can get almost anything you would need in a hurry. Breakfast cafes are also abound right across the street there is a McDonald's and St. Marc/ Chococro Cafe. The station building housing the Krispy Kreme and Starbucks was being renovated when I went there but should be opening back up sometime soon.There are also tons of bars located in the streets behind the station building and also Hooters a few steps away from the hotel.Some of the bad points:no bath in the bathroomrestaurant is incredibly overpriced for being so close to so many food optionspricey hotel for the quality if booked for regular pricehad to fish around for the mini bar pricing (kind of hidden away, I almost assumed it was safe to drink an iced tea)Room was a little stuffy, the A/C even on the strongest, lowest temp setting barely got the job done and I can imagine it would be worse if you stayed early/mid August.No pool or fitness center that I could see despite it being advertised on some of the hotel booking sites.This hotel would be perfect for a business trip as the room is comfortable, English is spoken and there are plenty of ways to get around and eat nearby.

This 4 star hotel is very ideal for your tokyo trip the location is well situated. There are lots of retaurant in the nearby place..This is a typical Japanese hotel, small but comfortable. Great location to major subway lines, the staff is very helpful, this is the perfect base to go around to tokyo.. You have 7-11 on the door step of the hotel, if you love chocolate hmmm on the same building they have godiva the best chocolate in town. A few step more there's a Hooter's Bar and if you croos the road you will find a lots of restaurant and KTV, also infront of the hotel you have mcdonalds. The room was clean and the bed is comportable, they have free wifi in the lobby but they have free wired internet inside the room, that is the only cons of this hotel as i have to go down at the loby to use face time other than that its a very good hotel with very friendly staff. I love the location of this hotel so probably i will come back here on my next visit to Tokyo..

I have stayed here numerous times whenever I visit Tokyo. The train line Akasaka-Mitsuke is just across the road and convenient to access Shibuya, Omote-Sando, etc. The food streets opposite also makes looking for food easy.

This is a good hotel to stay at, especially given that it is well connected to all parts of the Tokyo Metro with nearly 4 lines passing through the closest station. Also, the airport limo bus service makes a stop at the hotel, making it easy to commute from the airport. For tourists, the hotel is on the route for some of the daily city tour operators making it a good choice also. The food is also good both in the hotel and nearby areas.

The room size is enough for me and can stil accomodate another one. The bed is comfy, enough number of pillows, with espresso machine, wifi, kettle, a tv, a speaker if you want to listen to your phone, a hairdryer, a dress presser, slippers, the amount of shampoo, conditioner and body wash is more than enough and are replenished everyday... just about everything i need! The location is also perfect... near shops, metro station, near restos, bus stops..The service is also superb.. i called twice and the response is within a flash! :)No idea about swimming facilities or fitness center as I was in a business trip. Otherwise, I hope they have as a big plus.If I am to suggest for improvement... i think it would be adding beans in their breakfast menu and addition of lotion/moisturizer in their toiletries. :)

We spent the first two nights of our trip here sleeping, eating, and making mini excursions on the Tokyo subway trying to adjust to the time change. There is a subway station across the street. The reception staff include excellent language speakers , equipped with maps and local expertise, and the hotel is served by a limousine/bus from Narita airport. McDonalds is across the street and espresso is a ail able for free in the room. Our room had two almost double. Ed's and was quiet despite being above the street.

Certainly a four star hotel (at the lower end of the four stars), the property manages to be practical, clean, comfortable, without any X-factor to guarantee repeat patronage.The location is terrific. Right opposite Asakasa's restaurant avenue and xxxx shopping mall, you do not have to go far to kill time shopping or find an excellent meal. Rooms are mid-sized for Japan, hard, comfortable bed and pillows, small but perfectly functional bathroom with a deep bath, nicely decorated in softer, understated tones, certainly neither chic contemporary or decoratively chintzy in style. Kind of pleasantly forgettable. The white paper window shades are a nice touch.The one improvement they could make is double-glazing the windows. You can hear the traffic outside even from the 11th floor.I missed breakfast so can not comment. Nor can I mention any gym, sauna or pool as these are off-limits to anyone with a tattoo (could be Yakuza, you see). That's pretty standard in Japan.All up, a very comfortable stay, no complaints, in a very good location.

The bad first - we booked a slightly bigger room for three through hotels.com. The room is very small and only just fits the little toddler bed we brought with us. The room is also stuffy as we can't get the ac below 20. I thought it was a bit dusty and not so clean.The good free water in our room as we stayed more than 4 nights, free nespresso coffee, free wifi,comfortable bed - first one after 10 days of futon! Nice efficient staff and great location. Lots of restaurants nearby, metro with lift across the road and it feels safe. Business goes to the airport from outside the hotel. A fine accommodation option for a city.

Good quality business oriented hotel- clean, safe, - in a great location as a base of operations. Rooms typical Tokyo mid range hotel with hi tech toilet and great shower. Four(4) major subway lines across the street (Directional signs and kiosk for purchasing tix are in English)and airport limo bus to Narita direct to hotel. Nothing fancy, staff with acceptable English skills. Avoid hotel complex restaurants and walk across the street - everything from bakeries to McD's to high end all within 5 min walk. 7-11 in bldg and Citibank ATM nearby. As others noted, only English TV is a BBC news feed. Teapot (black and green tea, replenished daily)and single serve coffee maker in room a plus. You can use United MileagePlus miles through the United website to book a stay here with no hassles.

The rooms did appear bigger in the pictures I saw of the hotel, however it was very adequate for our needs. The beds were comfortable, and the heated toilets were welcomed considering the cold temperatures. One of the great things about the hotel was its location. Right across the street are many convenience stores (7-11, Daily Yamazaki, Lawsons...) Tasty sandwiches, bento boxes, and pastries are sold fresh daily. There are numerous places to choose from to eat...from Japanese, to Italian, to American. The staff was very friendly and accomodating. My family booked 2 rooms. We noticed that the air conditioners were not working too well. We called the front desk, and someone came to check on it within 5 minutes. Since there wasn't anything they could do about it, we were asked if we wanted to move that day. That simple. The hotel even provides the service of boxing up items if you've run out of luggage space (small fee for the box). Our trip to Tokyo was very enjoyable due in part to our stay at the Excel. We will stay there again.

The hotel is located in a predominantly business/government district of Tokyo. It's also very central and has easy access to the subway (which is just across the road) which makes it a great place to stay if you plan on looking around the entire city. There is also a 7-Eleven in the hotel which is handy for overseas visitors as 7-Elevens and Post Offices are some of the few places you can withdraw money from foreign credit cards. There is a Limousine bus service from Narita airport which stops at the hotel, though it is quite a long journey by bus and you might find it faster to travel by subway. The room we stayed in had a full queen sized bed and quite a bit of floor space as well. Overall it seemed considerably larger than the usual Tokyo hotels. All facilities were clean and well maintained and the room even had a Nespresso pod coffee machine.Staff were all very friendly and helpful and spoke quite good english

The best thing about this hotel is indeed its central location. The metro stop is just across the road and all convenient lines to get to other areas stop there. On arrival we were shown a double room with one bed while we had requested twin beds. Unfortunately no twin beds were available for that night so we could switch rooms after our first night (we stayed 6 nights in total). In this way we have seen both the double and twin rooms. Both were really small and the layout wasn't always as clever. It felt very cramped. Both rooms looked kind of tired and run down although they were clean. Service at the front desk was ok, nothing too remarkable compared to other hotels in Japan we have stayed in. During our trip throughout Japan we have stayed in several different hotels, ranging from luxury to a stay at a temple, but this was in fact our most disappointing stay. The hotel is too large and business like, the rooms are too small and apart from its location nothing was really outstanding. Since the hospitality standard in Japan is rather high, there must be better options in Tokyo for the same price.

First of all, the location is wonderful. Easy to find, good metro access, located in central part of Tokyo. Akasaka is nice place for stay for business people, for it is much quieter than huge station like Shinjuku or Shibuya, easy to go through the station. The hotel itself is very efficient, the room is spacious enough, nice bed and bath. Since this hotel has many options, when you book you should aware of room types. The hotel has many rooms without bathtub, just shower booth, which is yet unusual in Japan. The price is reasonable for its quality. At 1st floor there's Seven Eleven Convenience Shop where you can draw Japanese money with international credit card. Also there's coffee shops, wine bars, sake bars, sandwich shops, etc, in the neighborhood.

I stayed here for a business meeting. The hotel can be easily reached from Narita airport with the Limousine bus (which stops at the hotel). Good: good quality restaurant, very helpful and friendly staff. Not so good: you cannot open the windows so you're dependent on the A/C which was not switched on when I was there. Also, the rooms are quite small (I stayed in a single room). However overall I had a good experience. Internet is free and very reliable.

The hotel is good to reach by Limousine bus from Narita Airport. The rooms can be quite small if you do not choose a full double. Internet is free and the location is good and close to Akasaka business district. There is a charge for early check in - As most of the european flights get in to Tokio very early - you need to pay an extra if you want to get into the room before 2 pm. If you book the ANA you do not have to pay this! I did not go for the breakfast as there was always a huge line at the restaurant. There are better and much cheaper alternatives for breakfast very close to this hotel

I stayed in this hotel for three nights on a business trip. All my expenses were paid so I can't really comment on value for money. The hotel rooms were adequate but there were no non-smoking rooms available and the smell was terrible. Wish I'd thought to ask for non-smoking. The bed was extremely firm, the pillows good and the window opened so I could get fresh air. The tv had many Channel's but only one English one (BBC news) so a bit boring. you could buy movies if you wanted. There is free wifi in the lobby for only 10 minutes very 3 hours. There are computers you can use for ¥100 for 15 minutes. I found the taff helpful but their English was not great. There is a 7/11 downstairs and ATM in there too. The hotel is not in a shopping district but rather a restaurant district. If you cross the road and walk behind the buildings that line the street you'll find the streets teeming with people looking for dinner. The subway is very close. Taxi's readily available and a Starbucks along the street a bit. There is also a Hooters in the building. If you are looking for a fun evening go to the Ninja restaurant which is on the corner near the hotel.

Stayed in this hotel for 4 nights... Very boring location with only food eateries opposite the hotel.. Metro is just across the road and you can easily hop into the Metro to town for some shopping and sightseeing.. Almost like a dead town at night.. Rooms are small but clean and acceptable.. Would not really recommend holiday makers to stay in this hotel due to the location..

I was on a business trip to Tokyo for 5 days, and was initially planning on staying at ANA Intercontinental, but as they were booked out, chose the Excel Hotel, Akasaka, Tokyo. The hotel was nice with quintessential Tokyo style compact rooms with all the necessary amenities in the room (except an iron, for which one needs to call them in). The kit in the room is also fine. In true Japanese style, the service is very good.The internet in the room is through a LAN connection (no wi-fi) which could be painful when you want to relax at the end of a busy day at work.The location is very central, especially with the Akasaka-mitsuke Subway station(Ginza line) a stone's throw away from the hotel, making it convenient to travel across the city.The breakfast, which was included in the price, was a large spread, but being a vegetarian I obviously had limited choice. Even then, I always left satisfied with a good collection of international bakery products, variety of cut fruits and vegetables.My Pain area, and this is the one that sweeps off ALL the good things mentioned above, is when I had to make the payment. They do not accept any MASTERCARD Credit cards (3 of mine they didnt accept) , although on day 1 they had swiped my card for checking (and due to some reason, some money was also debited from my account, which they refused to believe!). Finally , because I had a local contact, he really went out of his way and paid for it through his Japanese card to sort out the issue at the moment, but I left very very unimpressed. At the end of the day, however good the hotel can be, this hygiene issue makes it really a painful experience.

I found the rooms small and boring. I was here for a week on business so some nights wanted to relax in the room which I couldn't do without wireless or English speaking TV. Have to request an iron, hangers everything you need basically isn't kept in the room. Bathrooms were clean but looked as though they weren't originally there and erected at a later stage, felt like a plane bathroom. Aircon wouldn't cool the room down in the middle of summer. Didn't feel this catered to a business need at all.Staff are friendly but with very very limited English. Try telling them the iron they just brought you is broken!Would like to try somewhere else next time. This really is a three star hotel and would be suitable for short time travellers who spend no time in the room.

First trip to Tokyo, and this hotel was ideally suited - not for sightseeing around the hotel, but for jumping on the Metro across the street. The Akaska is in the center of town with one of the main lines, the Ginza, stopping right in front. It was very convenient to get to either side of town in 15 minutes or less from the hotel, and if you are so inclined, east to get from the airport via the metro.The service was very good, and the rooms were clean, but small. Overall it is a good business style hotel in a great location. - and have a drink at the Ninja Bar next door!

I just left here last week and really enjoyed my stay at the Akasaka Excel Tokyo. I found the room clean (would be very, very rare for a Japanese hotel to not be), well laid out and a typical size for Tokyo hotels (cozy). Found it to quiet and tranquil. Staff was helpful with moderate English ability.I felt was the hotel was a good value for what it offers.Modern decor with light greys and browns and 4 different types of pillows on the bed with a white cotton duvet. Small table with chair. Nespresso Coffee Machine with capsules refilled daily. Also tea kettle in drawer. No bathtub, but shower has several jets and a hand held attachment. Latest TOTO toilet and bidet. Enjoyed the breakfast buffet every morning - many Japanese options and scrambled eggs with croissants and toast available.You can access the hotel elevators from the street level. Hotel has a shopping mall that includes a HOOTERS and Tully's Coffee Shop. Best part is the 24hr -- 7-11 --on the street level. Their ATMs accept US ATM cards. The Aksasaka neighborhood across the street has every kind of restaurant you could want including Noodles, Yakatori, Sushi, McDonald's, Subway and Starbucks.  It was my third visit in the past year and I had been staying closer to Omotesando, but this hotel is much more centrally located. Across the street from the Akasaka Metro station where you can catch 3 metro lines to Ginza, Shinjuku and Shibuya etc.I will use the hotel in the future as my base in Tokyo.

I have just departed from the Akasaka Excel Hotel having experienced the earthquake on Friday. The staff in the hotel are very helpful however they have limited english. They kept everyone informed regarding transport options for the airport which were severly restricted.Under normal circumstances there is a bus which departs the airport and drops you right outside the hotel. It does stop off at a number of other city centre hotels along the way and generally takes about 2 hrs. You should purchase the ticket for the bus inside the airport. The ticket desk is in the arrivals hall and is easy to find. The cost for the bus one way is 3000yen and you can pay be cash (yen) or credit card. The bus operates about every half hour. If you have an early flight back to the airport beware that the first bus leaves the hotel at 6,35am and takes about 1.5hrs.The hotel rooms are small with limited space to hang clothes and no shelves. There are a couple of drawers beside the bed. The rooms however are comfortable and the shower has to be one of the best I have ever used. Breakfast is buffet style and has a good selection. There should be something to meet everyones taste. The restaurant is also quite good and the food reasonably priced for Tokyo.All in all this is a decent hotel with good service and if I have to return again on business I would use the hotel. It is well located with a lot of small streets nearby with small bars and restaurants. It is a short trip in a taxi to most of the main city centre sights.

A friend of mine stayed in this hotel and recommended this since it was pretty central. I'm so glad we did. It's also a Good Neighbour hotel which means you can avail of their shuttle service from Akasaka to Disneyland/Disney Sea if it's part of your itinerary. My parents are not fans of Japanese cuisine (crazy, I know) so having a 7-eleven at the first floor, a McDonald's across the street and a bakery really helps. I liked the fact that internet was free, and the train station is just across the street. Unlike the Grand Prince Akasaka or the Otani where getting to the nearest train station is a pain on your feet.

The first room was crazy small and grubby. The only chair was badly stained. Complained and got a larger cleaner room that was okay. TV only has one English speaking channel (BBC World). Breakfast nothing special and not available before 7am. Lobby has nowhere to sit. Free Internet is fast but cable only.

Stayed 4 nights,rooms were a little small but well laid out.Bathroom was a good size.We booked a twin room for 2 adults and 2 kids,so maybe this is why it felt small.It was in a good location with plenty of restaurants nearby and nice and quiet.7eleven and maccas close by also.Subway is across the road but be warned if you have large bags there is not always lifts so you will have to carry them up stairs.Also be careful not to get caught in the morning rush as they push people onto to trains as there are so many.The subway can be confusing but japanese people are so helpful so you should not have a problem.So if you are looking for a clean comfortable hotel in a quiet location this could be the one for you.
The hotel is nice. It is across the street from the Ginza, Marunouchi, Namboku, Yurakucho and the Hanzomon line. The hotel itself is Luke your typical 3 star hotel.

We stayed at the Akasaka Excel for 3 nights during a vacation trip. We stayed in a moderate double - the rooms were quite small (by Tokyo standards) and the hotel lobby + decor was nothing more than a reception placed on the 3rd floor. We had stayed at the DaiIchi hotel and the Tokyo Dome hotel during the same trip, and both those hotels had impressive hotel decor along with bigger rooms for little extra for a double. The location of the hotel, however, is helpful as it is bang opposite Akasaka Mitsuke station, which has a direct connection to the Tokyo station. There is also the Airport limousine just outside the hotel. The service was satisfactory, as is in most of good Tokyo hotels.

I stayed here for 4 nights, it was clean, convenient and very quiet.The hotel is near a Metro line so it's easy to make your way around plus there's plenty of places to eat nearby if you can't be bothered to make the effort.

This is my 2nd time staying in this hotel. I would definite coming back again 1) Location : Airport Limobus service stop at this hotel . Akasaka Mistuke subway is just opposite,and it's serving 2 important subway line : Ginza and Marunouchi Line . Disney Good neighbour hotel, which has a bus to ferry to Tokyo disneyland. A lot of eatery opposite to the hotel. In addition, there is a 7-11 at the 1st floor.2) Room : typical 22sqm room for a Japanese hotel. However, as a mid-range price hotel, the room is consider large. It's recommend to stay at room facing the street side of the building as it's brighter . If u prefer a quieter side, the back side of the hotel is facing a garden and a building, however, it's quiet dark . The Room is clean . All the required stuff are there, they even have a Nespresso coffee machine. However, 1 drawback is the lack of clothes hanger, which i have a jacket and several long sleeve shirt. Anyway u can request for more hangers3) Facilites : As this is a business hotel, it does not provide facilities like a gym or a swimming pool.As such ,its rank as a 3.5 to 4 star hotel. However, as a business traveller or a tourist, I dont really need those facilities anyway

We stayed here for our last two night in Tokyo after big skiing holiday in Hokkaido. It had been recommended by a friend for it's location and value for money.The hotel was very conveniently located - in the centre of Tokyo and just opposite the train station, which was handily connected to most of Tokyo. Also very easy to get taxis outside the hotel. The reception area was very nicely decorated and quite impressive. The rooms however were quite small - although very clean and pleasant, and we did have a nice view over some trees, which must be quite special in Tokyo! This may be a problem with Tokyo hotels but the rooms were very small, especially with all our luggage! The bathrooms were also very small and we felt that we were falling over each other quite a lot of the time. This being said, the room did come with its own Nespresso machine which was very useful for our early morning starts!I would recommend this hotel for its location, convenience and cleanliness, just don't expect a spacious room!

Good:- Very nice Kimono style sleepwear. I wanted to buy it but didn't have time to ask about it!- Spacious room- Very well maintained- One of the Disney Good Neighbour Hotel which i find is important to stay in one of these cos after a whole day of walking, you want to be just driven back to the doorstep of your hotel. The bus service is on time. They just pick up passengers from the hotel only so no stopping at other hotels. Took only 30mins int he morning on a sunday. Less than the expected 50mins which was gr8. - breakfast was gr8, lots of variety. Some changes everyday.- we stayed there as part of our 7D Central Japan Tour with ASA Holidays, so not so sure about the cost of it. I've checked out online hotel reservations, seem to be abt SGD200 per night which i think is reasonable. - Located near shopping area but i didn't do much shopping there because they look expensive- Convenience store just downstairs, good to grab a bite if you want!Bad:- Very expensive local calls ~290YEN for less than 10mins of local call. I stayed in Shinjuku Washington Hotel later and found out it was so much more cheaper 40Yen/3 min

We stayed in three different mid-range hotels in Tokyo, and this one had the biggest rooms and best amenities for the price. Our hotel room was much nicer than I expected – it has been recently redecorated and doesn’t have the IKEA feel seen in the older pictures on this site. It was also a decent size—not huge, but you could actually walk around the bed. The double bed comes with two memory foam pillows and two buckwheat pillows. The bathroom is compact but you can still move around in it, and it has a borrowed view thanks to the corner windows in the interior wall - just be sure the shades are down when you take a shower! I recommend you ask for a room on the street side of the building, or, if they give you one facing out the back, a higher room. They tried to move us to a "better" room across the hall because it was marginally bigger. However, it was slightly below ground level, facing a dirt patch and a cement wall, with windows that didn't open. The last part was the deal breaker for me because this is one of those hotels where the thermostat in your room doesn't work unless they've turned on AC for the whole building... which they hadn't... and it was so stuffy in there I could barely breathe. Fortunately, we were able to switch to a smaller room facing the street with windows that opened.Other cool features of this hotel: It has a 7-Eleven on the first floor, which means an ATM that accepts US ATM cards and a cheap meal are always close by; it is adjacent to two shopping complexes with restaurants and stores and even a post office; and there is a street running behind the subway station that is jam-packed with restaurants and clubs.It's also one of only 15 Disney Good Neighbor hotels in Tokyo, which means it offers free motorcoach service directly to the parks - no small thing when the alternative is a 30- to 45-minute subway journey that includes a long slog with your luggage through parts of Tokyo Station that don't have elevators.Also, unlike many of the other Good Neighbor hotels, it is centrally located right in Tokyo, not out in the suburbs—good if your Disney trip is at either end of your vacation and you aren't planning to commute out there daily, although it can be done. The hotel is directly across the street from the Akasaka-Mitsuke Metro Station, which connects you to the Ginza and Marunouchi lines. If you don't use the shuttle, it's four stops to Tokyo Station and then a 10-minute walk down a loooooooong hall with stairs to the Keiyo line for Maihama Station and Tokyo Disney.

My 3rd trip to Tokyo. So compared to other Tokyo hotels, i felt it was good value for money. Recently renovated. Nespresso machine provided free. 7-11 store on entrance level. Metro station across the road to get you nearly anywhere. Great food across the road. Limousine bus takes you straight from airport to front door. recommended. free internet.
